urn:contentItem:5X38-PS71-JC65-52V4-00000-00Senate tech critic to Facebook CEO: Sell WhatsApp, Instagram2019-09-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON DATELINESenate tech critic to Facebook CEO: Sell WhatsApp, InstagramBy MARCY GORDONAP Business WriterWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - As Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg met Thursday with President Donald Trump and other critics of the tech industry, the Senate's most vocal detractor offered a challenge: Sell your WhatsApp and Instagram properties to prove you're serious about protecting data privacy.

It may have been more than Zuckerberg expected from his private meeting with Sen. Josh Hawley, a conservative Republican from Missouri, in his Capitol Hill office. Zuckerberg left the hourlong meeting - one of several with lawmakers on Capitol Hill - without answering questions from a throng of reporters and photographers pursuing him down a hallway.

Hawley, though, had plenty to say. "The company talks a lot. I'd like to see some action," he told reporters. "I will believe Facebook when I see some real action out of Facebook."

Rather than moving users' personal data from properties such as WhatsApp and Instagram to the core Facebook platform, the company should put a wall around the services or, better yet, sell them off, Hawley said he told Zuckerberg.

Zuckerberg, who requested the meeting, "did not think that was a great idea," he said.

Zuckerberg "had a good, constructive meeting with President Trump at the White House today," a Facebook spokesman said. On Facebook and Twitter, Trump posted a photo with the caption, "Nice meeting with Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook in the Oval Office today."

No details were given on the meeting, first reported by the Axios website.

Trump has persistently criticized social media companies like Facebook, Google, Amazon and his platform of choice, Twitter, embracing conservative critics' accusations that they censor religious, anti-abortion and politically conservative views. Trump has claimed, without evidence, that the companies are "against me" and even suggested U.S. regulators should sue them on grounds of anti-conservative bias.

A Facebook spokesman declined to comment on Hawley's remarks concerning his meeting with Zuckerberg.

The popular services WhatsApp and Instagram are among some 70 companies that Facebook has acquired over the past 15 years or so, giving it what critics say is massive market power that has allowed it to snuff out competition.

Zuckerberg's discussion with Hawley touched on industry competition, data privacy legislation, election security and accusations by conservatives that Facebook and other social media giants are biased against right-leaning content.

During his visit, Zuckerberg also met with other senators including Mark Warner, D-Va., vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Mike Lee, R-Utah, a senior member of the Judiciary Committee, and John Cornyn, R-Texas, and Tom Cotton, R-Ark. He also declined to answer reporters' questions when he left Lee's office earlier in the afternoon.

Lee's office said the two discussed bias against conservatives on Facebook's platform, regulation of online services, enforcement of antitrust laws in the tech industry and data privacy issues.

Congress has been debating a privacy law that could sharply rein in the ability of companies like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple to collect and make money off users' personal data. A national law, which would be the first of its kind in the U.S., could allow people to see or prohibit use of their data.

Acting preemptively, Zuckerberg last spring called for tighter regulations to protect consumers' data, control harmful online content and ensure election integrity and data portability. The internet "needs new rules," he said.

It was Zuckerberg's first public visit to Washington since he testified before Congress last spring about privacy, election interference and other issues.

Facebook, a social media giant based in Menlo Park, California, with nearly 2.5 billion users, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators following a series of privacy scandals and amid accusations of abuse of its market power to squash competition.

The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting antitrust investigations of the big tech companies, and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general has opened a competition probe specifically of Facebook.

At Facebook's request, Warner helped organize a dinner meeting in Washington on Wednesday night for Zuckerberg and a group of senators.

Warner told The Associated Press he wanted Zuckerberg to hear his Senate colleagues' "enormous concerns about privacy and about protecting the integrity of our political system."

Their message for the Facebook chief was "self-regulation is not going to be the answer," Warner said. "I think Zuckerberg understood that."

Warner and Hawley have proposed legislation that would force the tech giants to tell users what data they're collecting and how much it's worth. The proposal goes to the heart of Big Tech's hugely profitable business model of commerce in users' personal data. The companies gather vast data on what users read and like, and leverage it to help advertisers target their messages to individuals they want to reach.

The tech companies view with particular alarm a separate legislative proposal from Hawley that would require them to prove to regulators that they're not using political bias to filter content. Failing to secure a bias-free audit from the government would mean a social media platform loses its long-held immunity from legal action.

urn:contentItem:5X38-MS91-JCB8-W0MW-00000-00Senate tech critic to Facebook CEO: Sell WhatsApp, Instagram2019-09-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisBPg. 5Senate tech critic to Facebook CEO: Sell WhatsApp, InstagramMARCY GORDON AP Business Writer;

WASHINGTON (AP) - The Senate's most vocal critic of the tech industry offered a challenge Thursday to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg: Sell your WhatsApp and Instagram properties to prove you're serious about protecting data privacy.

It may have been more than Zuckerberg expected from his private meeting with Sen. Josh Hawley, a conservative Republican from Missouri, in his Capitol Hill office. Zuckerberg left the hourlong meeting - one of several with lawmakers on Capitol Hill - without answering questions from a throng of reporters and photographers pursuing him down a hallway.

Hawley, though, had plenty to say. "The company talks a lot. I'd like to see some action," he told reporters. "I will believe Facebook when I see some real action out of Facebook."

Rather than moving users' personal data from properties such as WhatsApp and Instagram to the core Facebook platform, the company should put a wall around the services or, better yet, sell them off, Hawley said he told Zuckerberg.

Zuckerberg, who requested the meeting, "did not think that was a great idea," he said.

A Facebook spokesman declined to comment.

The popular services are among some 70 companies that Facebook has acquired over the past 15 years or so, giving it what critics say is massive market power that has allowed it to snuff out competition.

Zuckerberg's discussion with Hawley touched on industry competition, data privacy legislation, election security and accusations by conservatives that Facebook and other social media giants are biased against right-leaning content.

During his visit, Zuckerberg also met with other senators including Mark Warner, D-Va., vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, and Mike Lee, R-Utah, a senior member of the Judiciary Committee. He also declined to answer reporters' questions when he left Lee's office earlier in the afternoon.

Lee's office said the two discussed bias against conservatives on Facebook's platform, regulation of online services, enforcement of antitrust laws in the tech industry and data privacy issues.

Congress has been debating a privacy law that could sharply rein in the ability of companies like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple to collect and make money off users' personal data. A national law, which would be the first of its kind in the U.S., could allow people to see or prohibit use of their data.

Acting preemptively, Zuckerberg last spring called for tighter regulations to protect consumers' data, control harmful online content and ensure election integrity and data portability. The internet "needs new rules," he said.

It was Zuckerberg's first public visit to Washington since he testified before Congress last spring about privacy, election interference and other issues.

Facebook, a social media giant based in Menlo Park, California, with nearly 2.5 billion users, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators following a series of privacy scandals and amid accusations of abuse of its market power to squash competition.

The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting antitrust investigations of the big tech companies, and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general has opened a competition probe specifically of Facebook.

At Facebook's request, Warner helped organize a dinner meeting in Washington on Wednesday night for Zuckerberg and a group of senators.

Warner told The Associated Press he wanted Zuckerberg to hear his Senate colleagues' "enormous concerns about privacy and about protecting the integrity of our political system."

Their message for the Facebook chief was "self-regulation is not going to be the answer," Warner said. "I think Zuckerberg understood that."

Warner and Hawley have proposed legislation that would force the tech giants to tell users what data they're collecting and how much it's worth. The proposal goes to the heart of Big Tech's hugely profitable business model of commerce in users' personal data. The companies gather vast data on what users read and like, and leverage it to help advertisers target their messages to individuals they want to reach.

The tech companies view with particular alarm a separate legislative proposal from Hawley that would require them to prove to regulators that they're not using political bias to filter content. Failing to secure a bias-free audit from the government would mean a social media platform loses its long-held immunity from legal action.

FILE - In this April 11, 2018, file photo, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg testifies before a House Energy and Commerce hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington about the use of Facebook data to target American voters in the 2016 election and data privacy. Zuckerberg will be in Washington Thursday, Sept. 19, 2019, to meet with lawmakers and talk about internet regulation. The company said the meetings are not public and it did not give details on whom Zuckerberg is meeting with and what, exactly, he'll discuss. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik, File)

Andrew Harnik

FILE - In this April 11, 2018, file photo, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg arrives to testify before a House Energy and Commerce hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington. Facebook said Tuesday, Sept. 17, 2019, that it expects to name the first members of a new quasi-independent oversight board by year-end. The oversight panel, which the social network first discussed publicly last November, will rule on thorny content issues, such as when Facebook or Instagram posts constitute hate speech. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik, File)

Andrew Harnik

Sep 20, 2019( Voice of America: http://www.voanews.com Delivered by Newstex) As Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg met Thursday with President Donald Trump and other critics of the tech industry, the Senate's most vocal detractor offered a challenge: Sell your WhatsApp and Instagram properties to prove you're serious about protecting data privacy.It may have been more than Zuckerberg expected from his private meeting with Sen. Josh Hawley, a conservative Republican from Missouri, in his Capitol Hill office. Zuckerberg left the hourlong meeting one of several with lawmakers on Capitol Hill without answering questions from a throng of reporters and photographers pursuing him down a hallway.

Josh Hawley, R-Mo., speaks during a hearing of a Senate Judiciary Committee in Washington, March 6, 2019. Hawley, though, had plenty to say. "The company talks a lot. I'd like to see some action," he told reporters. Trump has claimed, without evidence, that the companies are "against me" and even suggested U.S. regulators should sue them on grounds of anti-conservative bias. A Facebook spokesman declined to comment on Hawley's remarks concerning his meeting with Zuckerberg.The popular services WhatsApp and Instagram are among some 70 companies that Facebook has acquired over the past 15 years or so, giving it what critics say is massive market power that has allowed it to snuff out competition.Zuckerberg's discussion with Hawley touched on industry competition, data privacy legislation, election security and accusations by conservatives that Facebook and other social media giants are biased against right-leaning content.   https://media.voltron.voanews.com/Drupal/01live-166/styles/sourced/s3/2019-06/4DDEB37E-4449-4C8E-8434-87D3E426349A.jpg?itok=w3vNMXTjFILE - Sen. A national law, which would be the first of its kind in the U.S., could allow people to see or prohibit use of their data.'New rules' neededActing preemptively, Zuckerberg last spring called for tighter regulations to protect consumers' data, control harmful online content, and ensure election integrity and data portability. The internet "needs new rules," he said.It was Zuckerberg's first public visit to Washington since he testified before Congress last spring about privacy, election interference and other issues.Facebook, a social media giant based in Menlo Park, California, with nearly 2.5 billion users, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators following a series of privacy scandals and amid accusations of abuse of its market power to squash competition.The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting antitrust investigations of the big tech companies, and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general has opened a competition probe specifically of Facebook.   https://www.voanews.com/s3/files/styles/sourced/s3/2019-09/AP_19129751999892.jpg?itok=Z4QWpnIMFILE - Senate Intelligence Committee Vice Chair Mark Warner, D-Va., departs after a meeting on Capitol Hill in Washington, May 9, 2019. At Facebook's request, Warner helped organize a dinner meeting in Washington on Wednesday night for Zuckerberg and a group of senators.Warner told The Associated Press he wanted Zuckerberg to hear his Senate colleagues' "enormous concerns about privacy and about protecting the integrity of our political system."Their message for the Facebook chief was "self-regulation is not going to be the answer," Warner said. "I think Zuckerberg understood that."Warner and Hawley have proposed legislation that would force the tech giants to tell users what data they're collecting and how much it's worth. urn:contentItem:5X3B-4PD1-DY9S-T137-00000-00Senate tech critic to Facebook CEO: Sell WhatsApp, Instagram;Senate tech critic to Facebook CEO: Sell WhatsApp, Instagram2019-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALSenate tech critic to Facebook CEO: Sell WhatsApp, InstagramSenate tech critic to Facebook CEO: Sell WhatsApp, InstagramMarcy GordonThe Associated Press

WASHINGTON - As Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg met Thursday with President Donald Trump and other critics of the tech industry, the Senate's most vocal detractor offered a challenge: Sell your WhatsApp and Instagram properties to prove you're serious about protecting data privacy.

It may have been more than Zuckerberg expected from his private meeting with Sen. Josh Hawley, a conservative Republican from Missouri, in his Capitol Hill office. Zuckerberg left the hourlong meeting - one of several with lawmakers on Capitol Hill - without answering questions from a throng of reporters and photographers pursuing him down a hallway.

Hawley, though, had plenty to say. "The company talks a lot. I'd like to see some action," he told reporters. "I will believe Facebook when I see some real action out of Facebook."

Rather than moving users' personal data from properties such as WhatsApp and Instagram to the core Facebook platform, the company should put a wall around the services or, better yet, sell them off, Hawley said he told Zuckerberg.

Zuckerberg, who requested the meeting, "did not think that was a great idea," he said.

Zuckerberg "had a good, constructive meeting with President Trump at the White House today," a Facebook spokesman said. On Facebook and Twitter, Trump posted a photo with the caption, "Nice meeting with Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook in the Oval Office today."

No details were given on the meeting, first reported by the Axios website.

Trump has persistently criticized social media companies like Facebook, Google, Amazon and his platform of choice, Twitter, embracing conservative critics' accusations that they censor religious, anti-abortion and politically conservative views. Trump has claimed, without evidence, that the companies are "against me" and even suggested U.S. regulators should sue them on grounds of anti-conservative bias.

A Facebook spokesman declined to comment on Hawley's remarks concerning his meeting with Zuckerberg.

The popular services WhatsApp and Instagram are among some 70 companies that Facebook has acquired over the past 15 years or so, giving it what critics say is massive market power that has allowed it to snuff out competition.

Zuckerberg's discussion with Hawley touched on industry competition, data privacy legislation, election security and accusations by conservatives that Facebook and other social media giants are biased against right-leaning content.

During his visit, Zuckerberg also met with other senators including Mark Warner, D-Va., vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Mike Lee, R-Utah, a senior member of the Judiciary Committee, and John Cornyn, R-Texas, and Tom Cotton, R-Ark. He also declined to answer reporters' questions when he left Lee's office earlier in the afternoon.

Lee's office said the two discussed bias against conservatives on Facebook's platform, regulation of online services, enforcement of antitrust laws in the tech industry and data privacy issues.

Congress has been debating a privacy law that could sharply rein in the ability of companies like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple to collect and make money off users' personal data. A national law, which would be the first of its kind in the U.S., could allow people to see or prohibit use of their data.

Acting preemptively, Zuckerberg last spring called for tighter regulations to protect consumers' data, control harmful online content and ensure election integrity and data portability. The internet "needs new rules," he said.

It was Zuckerberg's first public visit to Washington since he testified before Congress last spring about privacy, election interference and other issues.

Facebook, a social media giant based in Menlo Park, California, with nearly 2.5 billion users, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators following a series of privacy scandals and amid accusations of abuse of its market power to squash competition.

The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting antitrust investigations of the big tech companies, and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general has opened a competition probe specifically of Facebook.

At Facebook's request, Warner helped organize a dinner meeting in Washington on Wednesday night for Zuckerberg and a group of senators.

Warner told The Associated Press he wanted Zuckerberg to hear his Senate colleagues' "enormous concerns about privacy and about protecting the integrity of our political system."

Their message for the Facebook chief was "self-regulation is not going to be the answer," Warner said. "I think Zuckerberg understood that."

Warner and Hawley have proposed legislation that would force the tech giants to tell users what data they're collecting and how much it's worth. The proposal goes to the heart of Big Tech's hugely profitable business model of commerce in users' personal data. The companies gather vast data on what users read and like, and leverage it to help advertisers target their messages to individuals they want to reach.

The tech companies view with particular alarm a separate legislative proposal from Hawley that would require them to prove to regulators that they're not using political bias to filter content. Failing to secure a bias-free audit from the government would mean a social media platform loses its long-held immunity from legal action.

urn:contentItem:5Y1K-XDG1-JB20-G1SJ-00000-00Senate Trial Looms Over President Donald Trump's Davos Visit; Beijing Confirms Coronavirus Human-to-Human Transmission; Women Spend Two Hours a Day Doing Unpaid Tasks Like Cooking; Trump at Davos; Impeachment Trial Begins; Pro Gun Virginia Rally; Super Bowl Showdown2020-01-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTJon Hilsenrath, Rob Smith, Howard LutnickNEWSFinancial012102cb.231Senate Trial Looms Over President Donald Trump's Davos Visit; Beijing Confirms Coronavirus Human-to-Human Transmission; Women Spend Two Hours a Day Doing Unpaid Tasks Like Cooking; Trump at Davos; Impeachment Trial Begins; Pro Gun Virginia Rally; Super Bowl ShowdownDagen McDowell, Liz Peek, Cheryl Casone, Andrew McCarthy, Kristina Partsinevelos, Marc Siegel

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Tuesday, January 21st.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

President Trump speaking in Davos, Switzerland, last hour, highlighting the strength of the American economy. Trade deals, regulation, deregulation, getting out of the way.

Meantime, the impeachment trial officially gets underway on Capitol Hill at 1:00 p.m. Eastern Time. This coming after back and forth arguments from both sides of the aisle.

The pneumonia-like virus spreading rapidly in China. The number of confirmed cases tripling. What you need to know as it reaches major cities in China.

Investors on edge because of that coronavirus in China. We have losses across the board. Again, investors, they bet on what they can quantify, possible economic impacts. People are thinking about the SARS virus, what that did to the Asian economies. We have a 45 point loss on the Dow futures. The markets were closed yesterday as we honored Dr. Martin Luther King Junior on the annual holiday.

In Europe, there are declines across the board as well. A loss of about 1 percent on the FTSE 100 in England, the hardest hit there.

And in Asia overnight, the Shanghai composite sliding nearly 1.5 percent, its worst day in two months. But the worst performer, the Hang Seng, lost almost 3 percent. Moody's downgrading Hong Kong's credit rating, citing the months of ongoing protests.

Counting down to the Super Bowl LIV, and one of the most watched moments, the halftime show. We have a preview.

Here to break it all down with me, Turning Point USA spokesperson, Iraq War veteran, Rob Smith, columnist for "The Hill" and Fox News contributor Liz Peek, and "Wall Street Journal" senior writer, Jon Hilsenrath.

So we get --

HILSENRATH: I don't care about Super Bowl halftime shows.

SMITH: What?

MCDOWELL: Well, you can't --

HILSENRATH: Do you care about them? It doesn't matter.

MCDOWELL: You better -- you better stop --

SMITH: Come on. Halftime shows are fun.

HILSENRATH: That's when I go and get a refill.

MCDOWELL: You better stifle before I throw you off this set for saying -- that is blasphemy.

Meantime, we want to get to Cheryl.

Fears growing over an outbreak of a new virus in China.

Cheryl Casone has the details.

Hey, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Dagen, good morning.

Well, Chinese officials say that a fourth person has died from the corona illness. Several U.S. airports increasing medical screenings for travelers coming in from China. More than 200 people have fallen ill since just last month.

French President Emmanuel Macron says he and President Trump had a, quote, great discussion on a possible digital tax. The U.S. and France reaching a truce over the French tax that would tax revenue from digital services at big tech companies like FaceBook, Google parent Alphabet, even Amazon. Macron has agreed to postpone the tax until the end of the year. President Trump has agreed to delay tariffs on up to 100 percent of things like French wine, cheese, handbags. We can all breathe a little easier.

All right, Puerto Rico's governor firing two more officials there, bringing the total to three people after this video emerged of thousands of cases of supplies that were meant for Hurricane Maria victims. They were found unused in a warehouse. Protesters took to the streets yesterday. They called for the resignation of Wanda Vazquez. The National Guard says they are going to deliver some of those unused supplies to areas affected by the recent earthquakes that have been hitting the island.

And Delta divvying up a massive amount of money between its employees. The airline has announced it is sharing $1.6 billion with its 90,000 employees. Each employee going to get a check for 16.6 percent of their annual salary. That's about two months pay. But this isn't a first for Delta. They have doled out these bonuses for the last six straight years. The airline's always getting so beat up, Dagen, for, well, you know, cancellation, lost baggage, but at least they're treating their employees a little bit better over at Delta.

MCDOWELL: Yes, indeed. And that's why you get great service on Delta.

CASONE: I've heard.

MCDOWELL: That's my opinion.

HILSENRATH: How about lower fares? That would be nice.

MCDOWELL: Hey, I told you, you keep talking, I'll throw you off the set.

Meantime, President Trump speaking last hour at the World Economic Forum in Davos, touting the strength of the U.S. economy and trade.

Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have a tremendous upside potential when all of the trade deals and the massive deregulation starts kicking in, which will be during this year, especially toward the end of the year. Those trade deals are starting to kick in already. The regulations are kicking in right now.

And I see such tremendous potential for the future. We have not even started, because the numbers we're talking about are massive.

The time for skepticism is over. People are flowing back into our country. Companies are coming back into our country. Many of you who I know are coming back in with your plants and your factories. Thank you very much.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Jon, your reaction?

HILSENRATH: Well, the president want to be talking about the economy right now. The economy is in really strong shape. It's a great juxtaposition for him against these impeachment proceedings that are underway.

The one other thing I'd say is, I always listen when -- when somebody talks to what they don't say, and it was interesting to me that the president, in this global setting, didn't say anything about immigration, which is such a resining issue for him here in the states. He started talking about teaming cities in Europe. I thought, oh, now he's going to talk about migration, immigration, but he was talking about teaming culture and commerce. So it's something that just jumped out at me.

PEEK: I thought it was interesting, the clip we just showed there speaks to something I just wrote about on "The Hill," which is the possibility the economy actually accelerates in 2020. No one is anticipating that. Everyone's talking about down beat kind of numbers. The IMF came out with sort of down beat numbers for global growth.

I think with -- with the trade agreements in place, and also with housing beginning to surge, there's a real chance that estimates of growth are going to be going up. And as we go into the election, the economy is going to get stronger.

MCDOWELL: Well, but the IMF numbers --

HILSENRATH: Was that --

MCDOWELL: But the IMF numbers were raised to 3.3 percent, global growth from 2.9 percent. So north of 3 percent. And one of the central reasons was loser monetary policy, but also trade deals and the easing of tensions.

PEEK: Without a doubt.

HILSENRATH: I think it's totally reasonable to expect the economy to accelerate.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

PEEK: Yes.

HILSENRATH: You've mentioned low interest rates. You mentioned trade deals.

PEEK: But I don't think the American people know that because if you look at the headlines on "The New York Times" and all the other places, it's impeachment.

SMITH: Impeachment, impeachment, impeachment,

PEEK: But also things -- like "The New York Times" had a headline last week, manufacturing at nine year low or something. It was so misleading. It had to do with an index of sentiment about manufacturing.

HILSENRATH: Right.

PEEK: Really dishonest. And that's the messaging.

(CROSS TALK)

HILSENRATH: One other thing, low interest rates --

SMITH: Well, I think the great thing -- well, I think the great thing about this right now is that we have so many people who are getting a lot of their information via social media, via conservative influencers that they follow and so now we don't have to depend so much on things like "The New York Times" --

PEEK: I hope so.

SMITH: To kind of like fit the narrative. It's really true.

HILSENRATH: I --

MCDOWELL: But that is -- but that is where people on the left get it wrong because they feel like we need to educate you and tell you and explain to you how the economy's doing.

SMITH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: No, every American understands that.

SMITH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: If they can get a job, if they can get a better job --

PEEK: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: If their wages will go up -- going up, they know that.

SMITH: People know whether they're doing better now than they were a year ago or two years ago.

PEEK: Bingo.

SMITH: They know it. They can feel it. They feel it when they open their wallet. They feel it when they go to the bank. So people know. They realize. And they don't need to depend on "The New York Times."

MCDOWELL: I -- I want to just --

HILSENRATH: Can I just throw in one other point --

MCDOWELL: Really quickly, because I want to get to impeachment.

HILSENRATH: We talk -- we talked about low interest rates and trade deals helping the economy. Let's also not forget that those folks back in Washington, Republicans and Democrats alike, are spending like there's no nozzle on the fire hose.

PEEK: Yes, that's true.

HILSENRATH: It's just flying out of there, flying out of Washington.

MCDOWELL: Right, which is not conservative, but that's a conversation for many hours --

HILSENRATH: I'm just trying to rain on everyone's parade.

MCDOWELL: No, no, no, it is -- but it is. And it's something that comes up often because the Democrats are trying to use that now against President Trump and the Republicans --

PEEK: Which is hilarious.

MCDOWELL: Right or wrong, but they are -- again, but look how low interest rates are. Yes, and the market's not worried right now.

Turning to the impeachment trial.

President Trump in Davos, while here at home the Senate is expected to take up the impeachment trial again. The president's legal team released more than 100 pages of its defense brief, slamming the Democrats. The essential argument in the brief having, read it yesterday, is that the two articles of impeachment, Liz, that they do not rise to the level of impeachment, period.

PEEK: Exactly. They're not crimes. I mean that's the essential argument. I think people are going to be responding to that.

I -- I -- look, what we've actually seen, Jon mentioned earlier, for months now that this thing has been underway, no one has changed their opinion. The president's approval rating, if anything, has gone up, which I think is sort of interesting and does probably reflect the strength of the economy. But people are really not paying attention to this because I think that the Republicans did a very good job of representing the House inquiry and investigation and then vote as terribly partisan, very unfair to the president. Now, the Democrats are trying to do the same thing about the Senate trial.

I honestly think people are bored with this. You know, yes, there's going to be some audience for these next few crimped hours of presentation. But it's sort of like what happened in the House. We know -- everything's out there that's going to be in this presentation. And in this discussion --

(COSS TALK)

HILSENRATH: I think not -- not everything -- not everything is out there. We haven't heard from Mick Mulvaney and we haven't heard from Bolton --

PEEK: Yes, but that's if -- if they get to witnesses, that's a new thing. But this initial is not going to be.

HILSENRATH: But this is the business they wanted to see. Like, if the Democrats were serious about hearing from Mulvaney and Bolton --

PEEK: Yes, they would have done it before.

HILSENRATH: They would have taken this through the courts.

PEEK: Totally. I agree with you.

HILSENRATH: So, I mean, there's still -- there's still more -- like if there was a real serious investigation --

PEEK: Right.

HILSENRATH: We would have gone through the courts and heard from these people.

PEEK: But -- but let's talk about --

SMITH: And what you guys are both --

MCDOWELL: Let -- let Rob get in.

SMITH: What you guys are both missing is how much money the RNC has raised off of this sham.

PEEK: Yes, that's so true.

SMITH: I don't think that people realize, we're talking tens of millions of dollars they have raised off of this. It -- it -- it makes the president and the Republicans seem like they're fighting the swamp, which they are.

PEEK: Yes.

SMITH: It does really well for fundraising. This is money that they are going to need coming up in an election year. And I really do think that the Democrats overplayed their hand with this impeachment.

MCDOWELL: Well, let -- let -- we need to --

HILSENRATH: And, by -- by the way --

MCDOWELL: We need to go -- we need to move on because I want to talk about this, but let me end with this. They rushed it. The Democrats rushed it in the House so they could slap the label of impeachment on President Trump. They didn't pursue these witnesses because they wanted to get it done by the end of the year. Then they tried to argue, we need to impeach him now because he might -- again, not a constitutional violation, that they were preemptively impeaching him because he might do something during an election year. Then Nancy Pelosi sits on those articles of impeachment for about a month. It's just -- the American -- again, the American people can see what is going on.

And one of the two articles is obstruction of Congress --

HILSENRATH: Right.

MCDOWELL: Which is essential -- essentially the president defending the power of his office.

PEEK: Exactly. Yes.

MCDOWELL: That is it. So that's a lot of what you're going to hear during that impeachment trial.

Andy McCarthy is coming up in a few minutes, but I want to get to this.

The Virginia Second Amendment rally. There were thousands of pro-gun activists. It was roughly 22,000 people showed up. Holding a demonstration around the Virginia state capitol yesterday. The relatively -- the rally, peaceful, no injuries. There was one arrest. And I'll just point this out, that what I have seen in publications like "The New York Times" comparing this to the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville that resulted in the death of someone is just -- it sets my hair on fire because these are -- this is a grassroots rally of people in the state of Virginia where the majority of counties in the state have become Second Amendment sanctuaries because of what the Democrats that took power in Virginia have tried to do in terms of cracking down on people's gun rights and cracking down on the Second Amendment.

Governor Ralph Northam put this statement out yesterday after the rally. I -- the team successfully deescalated what could have been a volatile situation. And Charles Cook from "The National Review" writes this, you deescalating nothing barred that which was of your own making.

SMITH: Right.

PEEK: Amen.

SMITH: Dagen, I cannot say strongly enough how much I reject the idea that what happened in Virginia was any sort of white supremacist rally, anything like that. I reject it.

There are -- there were African-Americans at that rally. Antonia Okafor, who is a two -- a female too right -- 2A rights activist, spoke at that event. This group, started by Maj Toure called Black Guns Matter, those people were at this protest. So these were law abiding citizens of all races and genders exercising their constitutional right to bear arms. And there are so many people in the liberal media that would like to spin that and pretend as if all of these people were white supremacist, as if all of these people were trouble, that I fundamentally reject.

And Governor blackface, by the way, is not the one that should be calling for calm or anything like that. Like, he's not the one.

MCDOWELL: I want to point out too that people like Cam Edwards, who's a Second Amendment -- pro-Second Amendment activist, they put out letters to all of those people attending that rally before the rally saying, we stand together regardless of color, class or creed in support of these rights. This is not an insurrection or a violent protest. This -- and he pointed out, this is a grassroots movement where 91 of 95 counties in the state of Virginia have become sanctuaries where they will protect your Second Amendment rights.

SMITH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I am fired up.

More after the break.

MCDOWELL: President Trump in Davos for the World Economic Forum and back here at home all eyes on Capitol Hill. The Senate expected to take up the impeachment trial against President Trump today.

The president's legal team releasing more than 100 pages of defense, slamming -- yesterday, slamming the Democrats' charges, defending how the president handled his phone call with the Ukrainian president. Quote, House Democrats' charge of obstruction is both frivolous and dangerous at the very outset. The very suggestion that President Trump has somehow obstructed Congress is preposterous. The president has been extraordinarily transparent about his interactions with President Zelensky. The president was not obstructing when he freely released the central piece of evidence in this case.

Joining me now, former federals prosecutor, Fox News contributor, Andy McCarthy. Excuse me, Andrew McCarthy.

ANDREW MCCARTHY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: Andy, good to see you.

What happens today? This is about Mitch McConnell, the Senate leaders' resolution about how the trial will be handled. Walk us through that really quickly.

MCCARTHY: Well, here's what the Republicans would like to do. They'd like to have a couple of days of argument by the House impeachment managers, a couple of days of rebuttal by the president's counsel, about a day and a half to two days of questions by the senators that would be asked through the chief justice. In other words, they would submit written questions and the chief justice would put them to the different sides. And then what they would like to do is begin closing arguments with an idea toward deliberation and connect -- and in connection with that, have whatever argument they're going to have about whether they need additional witnesses and documentary evidence.

And this, I think, is going to be the sticking point today because from the Democrats' perspective, if the additional witnesses and documentary evidence are part of the case that they want to present, you would think it would be unacceptable to them to defer that until the very end of the case, on the precipice of having deliberations over the final verdict. They what that to be part of the narrative they're presenting. The Republicans are going to counter that, you know, look, if it was so crucial to your case, you would have developed it in the House investigation and we're not going to a allow that to happen. You should be -- you should count yourself fortunate that we're entertaining this at all. And we're going to have it at the end. So that's what the big fight today, I think, will be about.

MCDOWELL: Do you think we end up having witnesses at the end? OK, we've talked about this. There were three witnesses in the Clinton impeachment. They were deposed behind closed doors. One representative from the Republicans and the Democrats were present. It was videotaped. They did air excerpts of it.

MCCARTHY: Right.

MCDOWELL: Do you think we get to witnesses? Because, again, and correct me if I'm wrong, the Senate has to vote on these witnesses and it requires a simple majority vote, does it not? So the Democrats would need four Republicans to flip sides.

MCCARTHY: Yes, here's I think what the problem is. If I -- if it were up to me, I think the articles of impeachment are insufficient on their face and I would entertain a motion to dismiss them because we've already had a full-blown proceeding in the House. It's not like we don't know what the case is, right?

PEEK: Exactly. Yes.

MCCARTHY: But there's some sentiment among the Republicans that the trial has to have integrity in order for it to be accepted by the public as legitimate. And to some of them, that means there has to be at least some nod toward having witnesses. Seems to me that the Clinton impeachment formula is probably the best way to do that because they can get whatever witnesses they want, interview them outside the confines of the public Senate trial, and then what happened in the Clinton thing was I think it was Monica Lewinsky, Vernon Jordan and one other witness, they had the arguments about what was admissible outside the Senate trial and then they just played video snippets in a very kind of tight, short way. And that was the witnesses. That was it. So they could --

HILSENRATH: Will Justice Roberts have anything to say about whether witnesses show up?

MCCARTHY: Yes, this will be very interesting how this evolves because I've always thought the chief justice's role in the trial is more ornamental than substantive, in the sense that the Constitution makes the Senate in charge of impeachment, not the court. The reason the chief justice is presiding is because normally the vice president presides over Senate proceedings.

MCDOWELL: Because he's the president of the Senate.

MCCARTHY: Yes, but there's a conflict of interest, obviously, because if the president is removed, the vice president becomes president. So the framers thought it would be unseemly to have that kind of a situation. So the chief justice is there. But how much he has to do is questionable.

Chief Justice Rehnquist, when he presided over the Clinton impeachment, said, I did virtually nothing but I did it very well.

MCDOWELL: Andy, I can always talk to you forever. More time next time.

Andy McCarthy. Thank you so much.

We'll be right back.

MCDOWELL: Countdown to the Super Bowl. Shakira and J-Lo, Jennifer Lopez to us mortals, putting the final touches on their much anticipated halftime show.

Kristina Partsinevelos taking a look at how the performance can boost an artist's career.

Hey.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS: We know that it can do so, but I'm going to steal this quote from billboard because they said, you can't do a comparison apples to apples because a lot of these artists don't have maybe a current album, they don't have an upcoming tour, so it is difficult to really say, hey, this guy made this much one year and this person made another.

But, what we know from the past, and we do have some big stars, J-Lo, Jennifer Lopez, like you mentioned, and Shakira, they're going to be performing together. This is going to be a big thing for the Latina community because they're both Latina stars. I know that J-Lo, too, even put out a quote saying that this is going to be really good for the girls out there and it's going to be Shakira's birthday.

Both have done very well with sales, sold over 75 million records worldwide. But what does this mean for actual sales of albums? So we've got to go back in the past.

Neilson Music says Maroon 5, for example, they performed last year, they saw a sales gain, and that's who you're seeing on your screen right now, of 488 percent on the day of the Super Bowl half show. Then -- they even saw their songs downloaded just skyrocket. They had Travis Scott, the rapper, some of you may or may not be familiar with Travis Scott, he saw some of his music jump about 80 percent. This is also according to Nielsen Music.

And then it's not just about the actual sales. We're talking about streaming on Spotify. Justin Timberlake, for example, he performed in 2018. He saw a 214 percent increase just in streams for his -- after his halftime show.

But not everything's good. And I'm going to bring it back to this because in was a monumental moment in the halftime show. Janet Jackson, Justin Timberlake, we don't have video of it, we don't have video of it, but after that little slip-up over there, unfortunately her album didn't do as well. Damita Jo, she had no singles off of that album. And that's a big deal for her because she's had seven singles just off of one.

And if you're wondering how much does a ticket cost, the most expensive is over $21,000 for this upcoming Super Bowl.

And Demi Lovato is going to be doing the national anthem. So that's a big deal too.

SMITH: First of all, Janet's my number one, so got to defend her.

PARTSINEVELOS: I love you too, yes.

SMITH: Second of all, Liz Peek told me Travis Scott's her favorite rapper.

PARTSINEVELOS: What? Really? Do you sing along?

PEEK: You are such a creative writer.

PARTSINEVELOS: I'm impressed, Liz.

MCDOWELL: So, best Super Bowl performance ever?

Prince.

SMITH: Gaga.

MCDOWELL: Prince in the rain.

PEEK: Oh, yes.

SMITH: OK, that was amazing.

MCDOWELL: Do you remember that?

SMITH: I remember that.

MCDOWELL: Because I'm a lot older than you are.

SMITH: I think I saw it.

MCDOWELL: But it was during a -- it was during a downpour. It was -- it actually wasn't that long ago. It was 2007.

HILSENRATH: I think the best part of the Super Bowl is that the Patriots aren't going to be in it.

SMITH: Oh.

PARTSINEVELOS: You're suffering from fatigue?

HILSENRATH: I'm just a suffering New York Giants fan.

SMITH: Yes, long-suffering.

PEEK: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But they're --

PEEK: You're not alone.

MCDOWELL: There's some logic in that, though. That, again, you get sick of seeing the same people show up and play --

PEEK: Sure.

MCDOWELL: And you have two incredible quarterbacks, Garoppolo and Mahomes, say that eight times fast.

SMITH: Whoa, back to this Super Bowl. We've got to have justice for J-Lo. She was snubbed for an Oscar nomination. And --

MCDOWELL: You were very upset about that because you thought --

SMITH: I was very upset.

MCDOWELL: You thought "Hustlers" was this --

SMITH: "Hustlers" was a legitimately good movie. I'm sorry.

HILSENRATH: Oh, so we should have Adam Sandler up there too.

SMITH: Yes, exactly.

PEEK: Yes, there you go.

SMITH: Maybe he'll come and cameo.

HILSENRATH: That's it.

PEEK: Aye, yi, yi.

PARTSINEVELOS: The Chief, though, they haven't played -- enter the Super Bowl since 1970.

MCDOWELL: Yes, it's 50 years ago. And they were -- they --

PEEK: And, man --

HILSENRATH: It's going to be a good game.

PEEK: It's going to be a good game.

HILSENRATH: Chiefs and 49ers, it's going to be a very good game.

PEEK: It should be a good game. For once it should be a good game.

SMITH: For once.

PEEK: And it usually is not, right?

PARTSINEVELOS: For once?

PEEK: No, I mean usually it's so lopsided.

MCDOWELL: The Chiefs --

PARTSINEVELOS: I take some offense with you. I'm a little bit upset about that. It's fun to watch.

PEEK: Oh, it's fun to miss --

PARTSINEVELOS: (INAUDIBLE) those that don't really care, the halftime show.

MCDOWELL: The Chiefs were in the first Super Bowl, Super Bowl I. They played the Green Bay Packers. I said that yesterday. So the Green Bay Packers, denied. I love it.

Kristina, thank you.

PARTSINEVELOS: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: J-Lo all day and Shakira.

Coming up, 2020 market outlook. We're talking about it with the CEO of Cantor Fitzgerald, Howard Lutnick.

Kids making money. How much they're getting for allowance ahead.

We're back after the break.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Tesla slamming claims its cars have an acceleration defect. Cheryl Casone has the details. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Dagen. Tesla is responding to a petition filed by a short seller and Tesla stuck with national safety regulators. The petition calls for an investigation into the alleged problem which could involve about 500,000 cars. Tesla says that the accusation is, quote, completely false. There is Tesla in the premarket, down about $3.69.

The grounding of Boeing 737 Max jet having long-term effects on that company. Boeing reportedly is now in talks with various banks to secure loans upward of $10 billion to help the company deal with the ongoing situation. At least $6 billion has been secured so far. Boeing ended the last quarter with $10.9 billion in cash on-hand and apparently they need more.

And millennials are not keeping up with the older Americans when it comes to the housing market. According to the Federal Reserve, the millennials groups only owned four percent of American real estate last year, that's a stark contrast to baby boomers who owned a third of it when they were the same age.

Experts point to a larger amount of debt that they have and the higher median price of a home as major reasons that millennials lag behind.

But there's also Dagen, one other point to this, and that's that these millennials saw their parents go through the great recession, the housing crisis of 2008, obviously, and that kind of scarred them a little bit.

MCDOWELL: Cheryl, thank you so much for that. Cheryl Casone.

Impeachment in focus on the world stage, ahead of his speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, the president tried to dismiss today's trial as a distraction to our U.S. economic success.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We're bringing back tremendous business to the United States and they're all here to see. I'll be making the speech and then we'll be leaving shortly. But I think it's very important that the other is just a hoax, it's the witch hunt that's been going on for years and it's frankly, it's disgraceful.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Meantime, back at home, the impeachment trial gets underway later today. Joining us live from Davos, Switzerland, the CEO of Cantor Fitzgerald, Howard Lutnick. Howard, always a pleasure to see you.

HOWARD LUTNICK, CEO, CANTOR FITZGERALD: Great to see you.

MCDOWELL: Howard, is anyone talking about the impeachment trial there?

LUTNICK: No. In fact, as I -- as I walked around and asked international people about it, they all see it as a domestic issue. You know, he's running for re-election. They view the impeachment from a global stage as much more like the Democrats, this is their -- you know, this is their sort of try at taking out the president who has got of course a really good economy and really good economic numbers which he highlighted in his speech.

So that's sort of the way the world's looking at it, it sort of the give and take of Democrats versus Republicans.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Howard, can we talk for a second about stocks and interest rates. We ended the year on the stock market on a really high note. How much room does this market have left to run on the stock front? And interest rates are exceptionally low right now; do you see any indication that they're going to go up at any time in the future?

LUTNICK: So I love when Davos is nice and sunny because basically that's my outlook. I mean, look behind me. It's a beautiful -- it's a beautiful day. It's a sunny day. Gorgeous mountains behind me. That's what the U.S. economy looks like. And I think the rest of the world's economy is coming up.

So, low interest rates are going to keep the gas on the fire. You're going to see that. And the president's going to push for it. You're going to see that through the election at the end of the year.

So, low interest rates, maybe in a dream the Fed gets to knock them up one notch but it's unlikely. I think low interest rates; I think you've got a nice stock market going to keep creeping upward, creeping upward as you had at all last year.

So basically, I think the U.S. economy's in excellent, excellent shape. Slow growth, not what the president would like. But you know, in the two percent range, I think we're in really good shape and it's good to be American again. Last year was good to be American. This year it's good to be American.

MCDOWELL: Howard, what about the rest of the world, though? Is the -- is our -- is our strong economy, is that helping the rest of the world? Are we seeing a rising tide, so-to-speak, lift additional boats, say in Europe and even in Asia?

LUTNICK: Well, I think the -- I think the trade spat with China sort of helped the rest of the world. You've got now China going out, shopping for their own deals around to the rest of the world. So now they're investing their dollars and spreading it out less to America, and around the rest of the world.

The supply chain started moving away from China, start of diversifying around the rest of the world and I think you're getting a little bit of an uptake from all of that. So you're seeing the rest of the world doing a little better, you're seeing the IMF saying the world's going to do a little better. So I think the world's doing a little better.

But they're not -- look, Europe is in no way close to the U.S. The U.S. is in a strong position, it's going to continue to grow at a nice rate.

And you know, the European interest rates at negative, that's such an odd thing. I don't even know how to discuss what it means to have a negative interest rate. You know, that shouldn't even be on the menu. It shouldn't be a choice to say you have to pay to store your money. But that's helping -- at least it's helping Europe start to grow and maybe, maybe you're going to see Europe grow a little bit this year. That would be really nice.

MCDOWELL: If you bump -- if you bump into the president, tell him that, Howard. Liz Peek is here. She has a question.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: So Howard, one of the questions we've been talking about last day or so is whether the president's message of lower taxes, less regulation, could possibly percolate through to the heads of state in the European community and whether they might begin to follow that path.

I mean, obviously Macron has run into huge trouble trying to change their labor model, you've had 50 days of demonstrations and stuff.

But surely someone in Europe has got to begin to say, you know, maybe we need to change our path here and follow this guy, you know, and try and boost our GDP growth.

LUTNICK: Well, look, you're seeing it for sure in Greece. You know, they went from strong left to a -- to a middle right government.

You know, that's what he tried to do today in his speech. He tried to say, you know, in a very Donald Trump way, look how great we are, we are, we are, maybe you should copy us.

PEEK: Right.

LUTNICK: Only Donald Trump can do it that way. I think most other people would stare at their shoes rather than do say it that way.

But you know, that was his message which is we're doing well; maybe you should think about cutting your regulation and try to pay attention to your workers.

But the fact is, the U.S., he had a better set of cards than other people. You know, we don't have the union issues that France does and Germany does. We don't have the industrial -- you know, choking that a lot of Europe does.

So I think the U.S. continues to lead and I think it's going to keep the rest of the world a little higher and the fact that we took on China and we're still taking on China, I think it's helping the world. At least get its moxie back in being a little stronger.

So I think the U.S. is in a good place. You know, lots of time in Davos people look for pessimism and they look for, -- you know, every year when I come on the show, people always ask me, what are the dark clouds out there.

The answer is, look behind me, there just aren't dark clouds this year. I think 2020 is a repeat of 2019, a really, really nice, good year ahead.

ROB SMITH, SPOKESPERSON, TURNING POINT USA: So Howard, we see that a couple of emerging markets like Brazil, India, Mexico and Russia are expected to see more accelerations and growth in 2020, probably by about a full percentage point.

So what in your mind are the reasons behind some of that growth that we're getting?

LUTNICK: Well, look, you have -- you know, these economies, they need growth, right. So, Brazil, for example, it's a minerals country, right. It's a raw materials country. They've got off to export their raw materials.

If they can export their raw material, it's going to lift them up. So that's an example where if the world is growing and the IMF is correct and the world grows a little, they'll be able to market their minerals, they'll be able to market their natural resources and the world will buy them.

So emerging markets need to export, they need the world to grow to lift them up. And I think that's what's going to help these countries grow.

Obviously, Russia is all about minerals and mining, right. These are the kind of countries that need the world to grow to help lift them up and I think you're feeling it and you're seeing it and that's what's happening.

So the world will be up a little bit and that's -- I think that's good. It's good for the world. It's good for the world's people. I think we're going to have an excellent year, just like 19 -- just like 2019, 2020 feels really, really good and I'm much more optimistic than most. If you talk to most people, they've always got to put a dark cloud on it. There's just not one out there.

MCDOWELL: Not me. I'm a bond nerd and I try not to put dark clouds on everything. You know, fixed income people traditionally, again, they're looking for the negative. And equity people are looking for the positive.

But all I can say, Howard, is you enjoy that sunshine there in Davos.

LUTNICK: Thank you very much.

MCDOWELL: In the days and weeks and months ahead, Howard Lutnick, thank you so much, Howard. Great to see you.

Coming up, China virus outbreak growing, what's being done to stem it from spreading further? And we watched these markets; this is one of the concerns that's front and center today.

Plus, women working for free. The eye-opening number of extra hours they're putting in for unpaid tasks. Stay with us.

MCDOWELL: The deadly coronavirus, at least six people have been killed by the outbreak, nearly 300 infected, this is according to the National Health Commission. The number of cases now tripling as Beijing confirms the first case of human to human transmission.

It is sending Asian markets lower, sparking fears this could become like the SARS virus. Again, there were almost 8,100 cases of the SARS virus back in 2002, 2003.

Joining us now, Fox News contributor, NYU Langone Center associate professor of medicine, Dr. Marc Siegel. Tell us about this virus, Doctor. Great to see you.

MARC SIEGEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to see you, Dagen.

So, in the city of Wuhan, which is 19 million people, this virus appeared to emerge in a seafood market from seafood and they didn't know initially in China that it was transmissible human to human. They thought it was just people that were exposed at that market.

So by the time they figured it out that it was spreading from human to human, it had already spread beyond Wuhan. And that's actually the problem now. Because as you said, it's in Beijing, it's in Shanghai, it's in South Korea, it's in Japan and the mathematical model of this, suspects -- from Imperial College of London suspects that there's actually well over a thousand cases already.

It's very hard to track it because the Chinese health authorities are waiting until you have a confirmed case before they isolate you. Our Centers for Disease Control here likes to stay ahead of it and look at contacts, who was in contact with someone who has this virus, get them isolated. Otherwise it spreads around, especially since its flu season in China now as well.

So how do you know whether you have coronavirus versus whether you have the flu?

HILSENRATH: It's also Chinese New Year and you have a lot of people traveling.

But I wanted to ask you, why is it that so many of these flus and viruses seem to start in China? What is it about what's happening in China and how it's related to the rest of the world that it always seems to come from particularly Southern China?

SIEGEL: Jon, that's an excellent question. And I think that the answer we believe, health authorities believe it has to do with how close people live together and how close they live to their animals. That hasn't really changed.

Because most of these viruses start in animals, they either start in animals or in this case, in fish, in seafood.

So, close contact and then people spread it more easily. It mutates. It changes to a form that then spreads from one human to another. The coronavirus is very unstable so it mutates.

PEEK: Is there a cure for this?

SIEGEL: No, there's no cure for this. There's no treatment for it. But before everyone out there gets scared, it's kind of a cousin of the common cold. It's a severer form of the common cold.

And I think the biggest thing that's driving the markets today is fear. It's not even the virus itself because we saw that with SARS back in 2003, which is it did kill 800 people. It's nothing to take lightly.

PEEK: Suppress travel, remember -- if you remember, people stayed home because they were afraid of this. So it actually had an economic impact too.

SIEGEL: And that -- I think that's likely to happen here. Our hospitals in the West Coast of the United States are already gearing up for this.

As you know, some airports are already screening people. LAX, San Francisco Airport, JFK, looking to see people that come in with fevers and with heart rate changes. But Dagen, that can be from a lot of things.

SMITH: If they find out they have this, do they turn them back around or do they stop them from coming, do they quarantine them? I'm curious.

SIEGEL: They quarantine them at the airport and then they'll test them. And clearly if they have the virus, they're going to keep them out of the general public.

MCDOWELL: This is always a reminder of how great the CDC is in terms of operating and trying to get ahead and on top of these outbreaks, whether it's a norovirus or something like this. I think you agree with that.

SIEGEL: Completely agree with that and not just the CDC. It's also -- I understand that some of our major medical centers on the West Coast are preparing for this.

Again, don't want to spread the virus of fear here. But I expect we're going to see cases in California.

MCDOWELL: We've got to run. Thank you, Dr. Mark Siegel. Great to see you.

SIEGEL: Good to see you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, kids making money, how much they're getting for allowance, next.

MCDOWELL: More morning buzz, first up, any mom would agree, women spend two hours more per day than men cleaning, cooking and doing other unpaid tasks. Do the math, that adds up to more than 95 additional eight-hour work days a year that women work for free. If there was a paycheck it would a hall totaling nearly $1.5 trillion.

Liz, why isn't this changing more? Why isn't the -- I guess the duties distributed more evenly in a household?

PEEK: Well, I think that -- I think it happens to some households. Most women I know would prefer to do those things rather than to have their husband do it because I think the husbands intentionally screw it up the first time they try and you're like OK, I'll do it myself. No, I'm just kidding. I just think that's --

HILSENRATH: By the way, I'd call this strategic incompetence.

PEEK: Yes, exactly. I've seen some of that up close and personal.

MCDOWELL: But this isn't just men versus women, this is in a couple. I think this is an even -- like, somebody is carrying the load around the house and then the other person is playing video games.

SMITH: I think those numbers speak to how much we can sometimes devalue that type of work as well. And so, when you see the number like trillions a year, it's really --

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: -- financial compensation the only measure of a -- of a person's value and what they're getting back or giving for their time. I mean, very often this is part of running and raising a family.

SMITH: Absolutely.

HILSENRATH: It comes with all kinds of psychic value.

PEEK: You know, I actually don't like this story because Hillary Clinton in her endless, endless book about what went wrong in her election spends a chapter talking about how sad it is that she has to plan the family's travel, etcetera. And I thought that was the whiniest thing I ever read.

SMITH: Are you kidding me? You read it so we don't have to.

MCDOWELL: Well, let's move on to something less whining, kids doing OK without actually having a full-time job. The average child nets a weekly allowance of $10.00, adding up to about $500 a year. About two-thirds of parents asked say they do a weekly payout with nearly half of the children survey saying that they saved about half of the money. That's according to a study by RoosterMoney, a kids allowance and chores app.

Jon, did you pay your kids allowance?

HILSENRATH: No. I can't say we did. I guess we dropped the ball on that one. You know, I think a lot of families --

MCDOWELL: Now they're financially dependent on you, even well into college.

HILSENRATH: Well, they're going to college and I think that a lot of families and parents these days are investing in their kids getting in and going through college because the payoffs are so large in the long run that we end up kind of devaluing things like allowance.

SMITH: Well, I'm going to be the old man sort of like waving his fist (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: Get off my lawn.

SMITH: Because I didn't get an allowance when I was a kid. I mowed lawns for $10.00 an hour, and that's how I earned my money. And we got a soft generation.

PEEK: By the way, I know a 6-year-old who gets $10.00 for a tooth that comes out. The tooth fairy brings $10.00. That's inflation.

HILSENRATH: I agree with you, I didn't get an allowance either. I worked (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: I want to get to the -- I want to get to the story about the royals, so Harry is back in Canada. They're moving to North America. Harry and Meghan started their new life, Harry flew into Canada joined Meghan and baby Archie. Rob, you get this one.

SMITH: Oh, Megxit, yes look, they're done. I'm not super interested in this. I hope that they make a lot of money, Meghan Markle is gorgeous. I hope that they're happy. I mean, that's all I've got to say.

MCDOWELL: Well, that was --

HILSENRATH: For me it's like the half time show, it's like eh.

SMITH: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome to North America, Harry and Meghan.

SMITH: Yes, I mean, I don't --

MCDOWELL: We'll be right back. Maria in Davos next hour.

urn:contentItem:5R4P-P1D1-JBHT-D401-00000-00Senator Al Franken Announced That He Will Resign From The U.S. Senate In The Coming Weeks But Did Not Specifically Say The Exact Date;2017-12-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisSenator Al Franken Announced That He Will Resign From The U.S. Senate In The Coming Weeks But Did Not Specifically Say The Exact Date;LanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I hope that he'll do the right thing and step aside.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I feel there have been a series of allegations that are serious that when he speaks to the nation and to folks back in Minnesota to be the best step for him to step down.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I do not feel that he should continue to serve. Everyone will make their own judgment. I hope they do make their own judgment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, HOST, FOX NEWS: Senator Al Franken baffled under democrat pressure says he will resign. But quote, "In coming weeks" as he strongly defends himself against allegations of sexual misconduct. This is bare-knuckle political hardball. The push is now on for a democrat Senate majority to upend the Trump agenda. We have the details.

Also the House is passing a two week spending bill to avoid a government shutdown tomorrow night. This continuing resolution simply renews all existing programs for -- through basically the stroke of midnight December 22nd. We're on that story for you.

And Bitcoin crossing the 19,000 threshold for the very first time today. This crypto currency is in a staggering dizzying ascend surging from about 3500 in mid-September to its current price.

Did you miss the chance to get in on the action or to short Bitcoin? We're going to let you know. We have an all-star guest line-up including the co- authors of the new bestseller "Let Trump be Trump," they are David Bossie and Corey Lewandowski, also attorney Gregg Jarrett on the Mueller probe, and Fox News host Steve Hilton on the fight between Trump and Britain's Theresa May, all here all tonight.

I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. Risk and Reward starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AL FRANKEN, (D) UNITED STATES SENATOR: We were finally beginning to listen to women about the ways in which men's actions affect them. I was excited for that conversation. Then the conversation turned to me. Some of the allegations against me are simply not true. Others I remember very differently.

I have used my power to be a champion of women. Nothing I have done as a senator, nothing has brought this honor on this institution. Nevertheless, today, I am announcing that in the coming weeks I will be resigning as a member of the United States Senate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: He struck a defiant tone on the floor of the Senate. Senator Al Franken defended himself before announcing he will step down but with the caveat in coming weeks. That's what the Washington, D.C. echo chamber into overdrive that Al Franken may be trying to buy time to get a new lifeline out of the outcome of the Roy Moore Alabama Senate race.

This, after eight women now accuse Al Franken of touching them inappropriately. More than three dozen Senate democrats call for Al Franken's resignation, including Charles Schumer, Bernie Sanders, and Diane Feinstein. Al Franken is the second lawmaker to depart over sexual misconduct allegations in the last week after John Conyers said he would require.

The push is now on in the Senate for the democrats to seize control. And here's the math if democrats win the seats from retiring Senators Blake and Corker and there is a Roy Moore Senate loss that will put the democrats up 51-49.

Let's bring in the co-authors of "Let Trump be Trump: The Inside Story of His Rise to the Presidency" David Bossie and Corey Lewandowski join me now. Good to see you, guys. First, what do you think of Al Franken resigning, first to you, Corey.

COREY LEWANDOWSKI, CO-AUTHOR, LET TRUMP BE TRUMP: Look, I'd love to hear the definitive date that Al Franken is actually to walk away from the U.S. Senate because in Washington, D.C., Liz, I think you're exactly right. He says he's going to do it sometime in the future. The uproar goes away and Al Franken still sitting in the U.S. Senate a week, a month or a year from now because nobody is going to force him out.

More than 75 percent of his own democratic caucus has asked for him to resign. He's made the statement let's get the definitive date when he's going to leave.

MACDONALD: You know, David, the republicans now have Roy Moore problem. The democrats, David, are trying to rebrand themselves as a party above moral reproach. But you know, none have given back the Harvey Weinstein donations. And only one, Kirsten Gillibrand barely criticizes Bill Clinton.

Go ahead, David.

DAVID BOSSIE, CO-AUTHOR, LET TRUMP BE TRUMP: Yes. You know, I think that we are going to have to have this conversation continuously over the next, you know, coming weeks and months. You know, I think that when Alabama voters decide next week then the Senate will get to decide if they want to take action through the ethics committee on then-Senator Moore if he's elected.

So, we'll see. Look, this is not going away. It's not a conversation that should go away. You know, the members of the media, members of the political class, you know, need to be held to account. And whether you're in Hollywood, New York, Washington, you know, I am glad that this conversation is happening.

MACDONALD: Especially with that slush fund paying off sexual harassment cases and more. Let's get back to Franken. Corey, Al Franken is saying while in office he has used his power against women. Let's roll tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

FRANKEN: You know, an important part of the conversation we've been having in the last few months has been about how men abuse their power and privilege to hurt women. I am proud that during my time in the Senate I have used my power to be a champion of women. I know there's been a very different picture of me painted over the last few weeks but I know who I really am.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right, guys. OK, of course, Al Franken will say that. He has already made similar statements. He also took a shot of President Trump and Roy Moore. But you know, you talked in your book about the Access Hollywood tape, Corey. What was -- we want to know, what was the first lady's reaction to that and the first family, the president's daughters, what was their reaction to the Access Hollywood tape?

LEWANDOWSKI: You know, Melania Trump said that she knows her husband and this was locker room talk. It was boy talk is what she said. And she stood by her husband. She was very clear. And the president has said that he never did those things, which is very different than what Senator Franken has said.

Senator Franken has now admitted that he has done some of the things he has been accused of, some of those women have come forward and said that he did this while he was the United States senator. We have a picture of him groping a woman's breast while she's asleep on an airplane.

Look, where I come from there is something called street justice. If you were to do that where I come there would be a very different resolution and potentially going to the Senate ethics committee to determine if this was right or wrong.

It is uncalled for, it's egregious and Senator Franken should step down immediately and not some arbitrary date in the future where he hasn't told us when he is going to leave.

MACDONALD: David, speak about the 16 women who have accused President Trump in misconduct. Go ahead.

BOSSIE: Well, it is exactly what Corey said, which is one is -- one is locker room talk. One is, you know, guys talking among themselves whether you like it or not we all know what happens and that's what the president acknowledge.

But there is a difference between photographic evidence like in Al Franken's case or in these congressional race -- congressional cases where they use taxpayer dollars to pay the women off. So, we know there is evidence in those cases.

MACDONALD: OK.

BOSSIE: Here there is just a big difference between the two.

MACDONALD: I want to get to FBI director Christopher Wray defending the FBI after President Trump's criticism as the president -- excuse me -- Representative Jim Jordan really pushed card on the Robert Mueller Russia probe calling for a second special counsel to look into the FISA warrant and how they came about to basically spy on Trump campaign aides. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JIM JORDAN, (R) UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Peter Strzok, Mr. Super- agent at the FBI, I think he's the guy who took the application to the FISA court. MACDONALD: Yes. You know, to Jonathan's point, Jason, do you -- would you get into it now or would you short it, what's your advice?

JASON ROTMAN, MANAGING PARTNER, LIDO ISLE ADVISORS: I would do neither. I would actually look at the other coins and other businesses in the block chain space that are much cheaper that have much bigger upside that do much more than just Bitcoin. Bitcoin is just money.

MACDONALD: Like what?

ROTMAN: There's other companies. Gosh, I mean, ethereum is kind of the second one to Bitcoin from a market cap standpoint. Ethereum is a whole platform there's another Chinese ethereum called nil. I think all these different companies have a much bigger future because they are the backbone of the whole decentralized economy.

Bitcoin is just money and I would not buy it up here especially.

MACDONALD: Yes, no store of value. Jonathan, what's going to cause this bubble to burst?

HOENIG: Well, you know, what's going to cause the bubble and the globe.com to burst. I mean, we don't know, Liz. That was, you know, a big tech of bigger play 20 years ago. Let's just emphasize, though, Bitcoin is not a currency. It is not a medium of exchange. It's not a store value. It's a speculation.

MACDONALD: OK.

HOENIG: And you know what this bull mark can continue to keep going but I wouldn't put my retirement fund there both in $20,000 coins.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: OK. Both of you think -- both of you think Bitcoin is a bubble in search of a pen. Jonathan and Jason, you both are great one. We want to have you back on soon. Thanks so much to you guys.

ROTMAN: Thanks, Liz.

HOENIG: Thank you.

MACDONALD: We will be right back. Stay right there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Well, it looks like there will not be a Christmas government shut down. The Senate voting to pass too temporary two week spending measures the House passed it as well, all to avoid that government shut down tomorrow night. The voting does continue.

We're staying on that story for you. We're simply with news all existing programs money for them through midnight on December 22nd.

Thanks so much for having us in your homes. Charles Payne is here now with Making Money. Take it away, Charles.

END
