urn:contentItem:5R4P-P1D1-JBHT-D3YD-00000-00Senator Al Franken Announced That He Will Resign From The U.S. Senate In The Coming Weeks But Did Not Specifically Say The Exact Date;2017-12-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisSenator Al Franken Announced That He Will Resign From The U.S. Senate In The Coming Weeks But Did Not Specifically Say The Exact Date;LanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I hope that he'll do the right thing and step aside.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I feel there have been a series of allegations that are serious that when he speaks to the nation and to folks back in Minnesota to be the best step for him to step down.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I do not feel that he should continue to serve. Everyone will make their own judgment. I hope they do make their own judgment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, HOST, FOX NEWS: Senator Al Franken baffled under democrat pressure says he will resign. But quote, "In coming weeks" as he strongly defends himself against allegations of sexual misconduct. This is bare-knuckle political hardball. The push is now on for a democrat Senate majority to upend the Trump agenda. We have the details.

Also the House is passing a two week spending bill to avoid a government shutdown tomorrow night. This continuing resolution simply renews all existing programs for -- through basically the stroke of midnight December 22nd. We're on that story for you.

And Bitcoin crossing the 19,000 threshold for the very first time today. This crypto currency is in a staggering dizzying ascend surging from about 3500 in mid-September to its current price.

Did you miss the chance to get in on the action or to short Bitcoin? We're going to let you know. We have an all-star guest line-up including the co- authors of the new bestseller "Let Trump be Trump," they are David Bossie and Corey Lewandowski, also attorney Gregg Jarrett on the Mueller probe, and Fox News host Steve Hilton on the fight between Trump and Britain's Theresa May, all here all tonight.

I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. Risk and Reward starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AL FRANKEN, (D) UNITED STATES SENATOR: We were finally beginning to listen to women about the ways in which men's actions affect them. I was excited for that conversation. Then the conversation turned to me. Some of the allegations against me are simply not true. Others I remember very differently.

I have used my power to be a champion of women. Nothing I have done as a senator, nothing has brought this honor on this institution. Nevertheless, today, I am announcing that in the coming weeks I will be resigning as a member of the United States Senate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: He struck a defiant tone on the floor of the Senate. Senator Al Franken defended himself before announcing he will step down but with the caveat in coming weeks. That's what the Washington, D.C. echo chamber into overdrive that Al Franken may be trying to buy time to get a new lifeline out of the outcome of the Roy Moore Alabama Senate race.

This, after eight women now accuse Al Franken of touching them inappropriately. More than three dozen Senate democrats call for Al Franken's resignation, including Charles Schumer, Bernie Sanders, and Diane Feinstein. Al Franken is the second lawmaker to depart over sexual misconduct allegations in the last week after John Conyers said he would require.

The push is now on in the Senate for the democrats to seize control. And here's the math if democrats win the seats from retiring Senators Blake and Corker and there is a Roy Moore Senate loss that will put the democrats up 51-49.

Let's bring in the co-authors of "Let Trump be Trump: The Inside Story of His Rise to the Presidency" David Bossie and Corey Lewandowski join me now. Good to see you, guys. First, what do you think of Al Franken resigning, first to you, Corey.

COREY LEWANDOWSKI, CO-AUTHOR, LET TRUMP BE TRUMP: Look, I'd love to hear the definitive date that Al Franken is actually to walk away from the U.S. Senate because in Washington, D.C., Liz, I think you're exactly right. He says he's going to do it sometime in the future. The uproar goes away and Al Franken still sitting in the U.S. Senate a week, a month or a year from now because nobody is going to force him out.

More than 75 percent of his own democratic caucus has asked for him to resign. He's made the statement let's get the definitive date when he's going to leave.

MACDONALD: You know, David, the republicans now have Roy Moore problem. The democrats, David, are trying to rebrand themselves as a party above moral reproach. But you know, none have given back the Harvey Weinstein donations. And only one, Kirsten Gillibrand barely criticizes Bill Clinton.

Go ahead, David.

DAVID BOSSIE, CO-AUTHOR, LET TRUMP BE TRUMP: Yes. You know, I think that we are going to have to have this conversation continuously over the next, you know, coming weeks and months. You know, I think that when Alabama voters decide next week then the Senate will get to decide if they want to take action through the ethics committee on then-Senator Moore if he's elected.

So, we'll see. Look, this is not going away. It's not a conversation that should go away. You know, the members of the media, members of the political class, you know, need to be held to account. And whether you're in Hollywood, New York, Washington, you know, I am glad that this conversation is happening.

MACDONALD: Especially with that slush fund paying off sexual harassment cases and more. Let's get back to Franken. Corey, Al Franken is saying while in office he has used his power against women. Let's roll tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

FRANKEN: You know, an important part of the conversation we've been having in the last few months has been about how men abuse their power and privilege to hurt women. I am proud that during my time in the Senate I have used my power to be a champion of women. I know there's been a very different picture of me painted over the last few weeks but I know who I really am.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right, guys. OK, of course, Al Franken will say that. He has already made similar statements. He also took a shot of President Trump and Roy Moore. But you know, you talked in your book about the Access Hollywood tape, Corey. What was -- we want to know, what was the first lady's reaction to that and the first family, the president's daughters, what was their reaction to the Access Hollywood tape?

LEWANDOWSKI: You know, Melania Trump said that she knows her husband and this was locker room talk. It was boy talk is what she said. And she stood by her husband. She was very clear. And the president has said that he never did those things, which is very different than what Senator Franken has said.

Senator Franken has now admitted that he has done some of the things he has been accused of, some of those women have come forward and said that he did this while he was the United States senator. We have a picture of him groping a woman's breast while she's asleep on an airplane.

Look, where I come from there is something called street justice. If you were to do that where I come there would be a very different resolution and potentially going to the Senate ethics committee to determine if this was right or wrong.

It is uncalled for, it's egregious and Senator Franken should step down immediately and not some arbitrary date in the future where he hasn't told us when he is going to leave.

MACDONALD: David, speak about the 16 women who have accused President Trump in misconduct. Go ahead.

BOSSIE: Well, it is exactly what Corey said, which is one is -- one is locker room talk. One is, you know, guys talking among themselves whether you like it or not we all know what happens and that's what the president acknowledge.

But there is a difference between photographic evidence like in Al Franken's case or in these congressional race -- congressional cases where they use taxpayer dollars to pay the women off. So, we know there is evidence in those cases.

MACDONALD: OK.

BOSSIE: Here there is just a big difference between the two.

MACDONALD: I want to get to FBI director Christopher Wray defending the FBI after President Trump's criticism as the president -- excuse me -- Representative Jim Jordan really pushed card on the Robert Mueller Russia probe calling for a second special counsel to look into the FISA warrant and how they came about to basically spy on Trump campaign aides. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JIM JORDAN, (R) UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Peter Strzok, Mr. Super- agent at the FBI, I think he's the guy who took the application to the FISA court. And if that happened, I mean, think, if this happened if you have the FBI working with a campaign, the democrats campaign taken opposition research dressing it all up and turn it into an intelligence document and taking it to the FISA court so they can spy on the other campaign, if that happened that is as wrong as it gets.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. You guys were on the campaign, tell us what was going on behind the scenes of the campaign. Did you, Corey, did you -- did you know anybody or anyone else connected to the Trump campaign who is working with the Russians to hack Hillary Clinton's campaign.

LEWANDOWSKI: Never. And let me say this. I sat next to candidate Trump for 18 months, 18 hours a day seven days a week. Never was the collusion, cooperation or coordination with Russia in any way shape or form.

And what I have said very publicly and I stand by. If anybody attempted to or did manipulate the outcome of this election for a foreign government that person should go to jail for the rest of their life. And that would include FBI agents who potentially used their power in the deep state to manipulate government agencies like in court to list -- enlist FISA warrant or to change rules and regulations as it relate to Hillary Clinton investigation.

I am gravely concerned about this agent. And right now all we know is that he's been demoted to the human resources department which I think is still circumspect at best.

MACDONALD: Yes, we're staying on the story here on this show. The Trump empires real estate dealings, David, with Russians and money laundering is now into the microscope. Have you ever heard anything about that any Russians were using shell companies or real estate dealings with the Trump empire.

BOSSIE: You know, we got these questions about our book. Why we didn't talk about Russia in the book. And the reality is because there was nothing to it. You know, we just look at this case and say it was based on this collusion accusation. And this investigation has been going on a year and a half now. Eighteen months of an investigation. Not a scintilla of evidence that there's been any collusion or cooperation between the Russians and our campaign.

And let me just say, we acknowledged that the Russians were trying to impact both campaigns and we disagree with that. We want them to never do that again. We want American campaigns to be stood up so that they can't be impacted again. And so we'd like to see that happen.

But there was no evidence of collusion. And that's why this case really has gone nowhere except Paul Manafort and Rick Gates in what they did before joining the campaign, and Mike Flynn and Papadopoulos about a lie they told to the FBI. Again, nothing to do with collusion of the Trump campaign.

MACDONALD: OK. Let's move on. Now, you know, the press is on. The full court press is on with Senate democrats to seize back control and get a majority in the Senate.

The Dow powering forward on optimism about the Trump agenda and tax reform. Look at this. It only took 32 trading days for the Dow to rise and 22,000 to the 23,000 mark. It was only seven days ago that the blue chip average finished above 24,000 for the very first time.

We're now in the fifth 1,000 milestone in 2017 for the Dow, the most ever in a calendar year. And the six 1,000-point milestone since Election Day.

But former President Obama is crediting himself for the strong economy saying the thank should go to him. Watch the fast fall that President Obama tried to whip by you.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: As we took these actions we saw the U.S. economy were all consistent, we saw the longest stream of job creation in American history by far. The streak have stock continues by the way. Thanks, Obama.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: OK. Did you catch the nuance of what Obama said, the quote, "longest winning streak." Obama is talking about back to back monthly job creation 75 months straight versus Reagan at 48. But when you talk about the actual number of jobs created Obama ranks down there with Jimmy Carter. Reagan created more than 16 million, Clinton nearly 23 million. About 11 million for President Obama and 10 million for Carter.

I mean, Corey, every president can argue they inherited the recession going back to FDR. That's what Obama is arguing. What do you make of those numbers and what Obama is saying that he's the go to guy for the strength in the economy.

LEWANDOWSKI: Well, you know, Liz. It's amazing. This is the 12 year presidency because for the first four years of the Obama administration all he did was blame Bush for the terrible economy that he inherited. And now for the year after this administration he's tried to take credit for what Trump has done.

Look, Donald Trump has helped to add 5 trillion almost $6 million of market cap to the economy right now. We have the lowest unemployment since 1973. We have the highest home ownership in two generations. What we see is the stock market is going like crazy. We're at 3.3 percent growth under the Obama years.

Look, these are the governments numbers, 1.2 and 1.3 percent GDP. He doubled our national deficit in eight years. From eight -- from eight to 16 and then from 10 to $20 trillion. The only thing he gets credit for is that Donald Trump came in to save the economy.

MACDONALD: And facts are he created a record number of basic government jobs, a lot of government jobs, a lot of minimum wage jobs that you can't raise a family on. Those are the facts. You can check the government data on that.

I want to get to the story first. Let me get back for a second to your new tell-all book "Let Trump Be Trump." David, you -- David and Corey, you detailed how ABC News top producer Chris Vlasto gave you, David, as Trump then-deputy campaign manager proprietary exit polling in election night. Those numbers are usually only shared with the Associated Press and the major TV networks and not to outsiders.

I mean, ABC I think you reported this, has now reprimanded the producer for that. How did this go down, I mean, how did you get involved in that. Did you feel badly about being involved in that?

BOSSIE: Well, I didn't feel badly about being involved in it. Look, reporters and political operatives all across the country in both parties trade information all the time. And it is just part of the business. And so I traded information with reporters for 30 years now.

And so I got that data and it was just -- it ended up being bad exit poll data. It's really what it ended up being. So, we took about half an hour to digest it and figure it out that it was bad exit poll data. We got it at 5, by about 5.35 we had figured out that we're not in as bad a shape as it looked like because the exit polls were wrong.

And Donald Trump ended up winning this massive landslide all across the country winning states like Pennsylvania and Michigan, and Wisconsin. States we weren't supposed to win. North Carolina and Florida by bug numbers that they did not expect the Clintons, you know -- when they got that same data, I might add, you know, they were celebrating and popping champagne corks a little early.

MACDONALD: Interesting. You know, you guys, you've worked with news operations with the TV networks for some time. We broke this -- we reported on the story about ABC News investigative divisions still reeling from the suspension of chief investigative correspondent Brian Ross.

The Dow dropped, Corey, 350 points by his wrong report about General Flynn and Trump. What has been your experience and can you tell you what has been like to deal with the various networks in the integrity and credibility of each of them.

LEWANDOWSKI: Look, I think there are some good people who work at the networks. But unfortunately, we're now in a cycle where reporters want to make the news and not report the news. We saw this from Brian Ross, he put out a false narrative. The Dow Jones falls 350 points.

ABC first has those in mistake. Now they've suspended him. They should fire this person for what he did. How many people lost money because of this false report? Look in just this week. We saw a report out that the Mueller investigative team has subpoenaed records at Deutsche bank. That story was pervasive across the networks only to be retracted in six hours later as a complete facade.

The news media has no liability. Unfortunately, the networks go and say whatever they want and their apology effort is not enough to the American people. And that's why Donald Trump -- and we talked about this in the book a lot -- coined the phrase "fake news."

The American people are smart, they look through it and 97 percent of the people after election they say they didn't allow the media's bias to change their voting habits this election cycle.

MACDONALD: All right. David and Corey, it's so good to see you, guys. Be sure to buy their best-selling book "Let Trump Be Trump." We love having you on. We look forward to both of you coming back on again soon. It's a great book, go buy it.

(CROSSTALK)

LEWANDOWSKI: Any time. Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: Let's check your money markets closing up 70 points today. Our own Nicole Petallides is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with the latest. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: A winning day on Wall Street. The Dow came off this earlier high. It hit the highest point in the day when Senator Al Franken said he was going to be resigning. It was up about 120 points.

But the Dow finished higher by 70 points. The S&P 500 seven points, snapping in the recent losing streak. The NASDAQ also gained. The winner will be that Caterpillar, Visa, Nike, Boeing, and United Technologies.

For the week all three are still slightly lower. Also tomorrow is jobs Friday. We'll watch for that with the estimates of roughly 200,000 4.1 percent. Maria Bartiromo love jobs in America especially here on Fox Business so keep it right here on Fox Business.

Back to you.

MACDONALD: Thank you much, Nicole. The Justice Department is now reading through over 10,000 text between FBI investigator Peter Strzok and another official. Initial text show anti-Trump bias but will the voters see them. Will they see all of them. And will more shoes drop in the Mueller Russia probe when it comes to bias.

A Justice Department official, another official involved in that probe now demoted over bias allegations. We've got the details, next. Stay right there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The attorney general needs to do his job and end this witch hunt charade. We have a clear double standard. And you see in the American people see it. Hillary Clinton is being investigated by her own fan club before the 2016 election. And the only way you seem to get on Mueller's team is to demonstrate a hatred for Donald Trump.

I think that the way Mueller built his team was finding people who had a bias against the president and doing everything he could to include them in this investigation.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The time is now for Jeff Sessions to do his job, and if he doesn't do his job, you know, he needs to step aside and let somebody else do it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: The Justice Department is now reading through over 10,000 texts between FBI officials Peter Strzok and Lisa Page. Strzok is the FBI official removed from special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe over alleged anti-Trump bias.

My next case is making the case that the Mueller investigation is illegitimate and corrupt. Joining me now, attorney and Fox News correspondent, Gregg Jarrett. Good to see you, Gregg.

GREGG JARRETT, ATTORNEY AND FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good to see you.

MACDONALD: Why do you say it's illegitimate and corrupt?

JARRETT: Because Mueller is back to deck. This is a team of investigators and lawyers that is rife with political prejudice and corrupt motives. And you know, Peter Strzok is just the tip of the iceberg here. When the inspector general report comes out I suspect it will be pretty damning evidence of not just what Strzok did but others.

And that may include James Comey that they fix it deliberately for political purposes that Hillary Clinton would be cleared so that it would enable her to ascend to the presidency. And when that didn't happen they set out to bring down the guy who won.

MACDONALD: And they just demoted. The Justice Department official Peter Strzok, right?

JARRETT: Right.

MACDONALD: For bias, alleged bias, right?

JARRETT: Look at the people that Mueller selected. Eight of the lawyers on his team are democratic donors including one, Jeannie Rhee who actually defended the Clinton Foundation into racketeering lawsuits.

The political opponent and the guy you are investigating. How could you select Jeannie Rhee and Andrew Weissmann we now know was fawning all over Sally Yates who defied the president.

MACDONALD: You know, Greg, democrats have been accusing President Trump of attacking the institutions of our democracy. Let's roll tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think our democracy is under attack.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Our institutions are under assault.

OBAMA: Democracy itself is on the ballot right now.

HILLARY CLINTON, (D) FORMER UNITED STATES PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This is his final target, our democracy itself.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: But CNN's Chris Cuomo actually pointing out the hypocrisy over what happened to Al Franken.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS CUOMO, HOST, CNN: Democrats have been attacking Trump for attacking democratic institutions. And now they're getting rid of Franken without due process.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. Due process, right, for Al Franken. I mean, some of these...

(CROSSTALK)

JARRETT: Franken was getting due process.

MACDONALD: Well, some of these allegations -- some of these allegations happened before he became a senator, right? But he wanted the investigation to...

(CROSSTALK)

JARRETT: He wanted an ethics investigation. And then the democratic leadership went to him and said you got to leave and if you don't we'll take you off every committee and get rid of you in other way. So, he quit.

Look, the clip you paid -- played are very revealing. They came from James Clapper who lied to Congress. Eric Holder who was held in contempt of Congress, and Hillary Clinton who likely violated the espionage actors. Overwhelming evidence of it.

MACDONALD: So you're just saying that, you know, it's sort of like pot calling the kettle black here, right?

JARRETT: Yes. I mean, these are, you know democrats who have a political agenda and animus for the president and they're lashing out. It's, you know, it's politics.

MACDONALD: OK. So, your forecast is that the inspector general report and the Mueller probe is going to see more shoes to drop.

JARRETT: Yes, but we can't wait for it early next year. I think you have to have Jeff Sessions un- recuse himself for the sole purpose of firing the entire Mueller staff plus Mueller and replace him with somebody who can be fair and objective.

MACDONALD: Yes. The bombshell. Gregg Jarrett, thank you so much. We love having you on. Come back soon.

JARRETT: Sure.

MACDONALD: Today marks the 76th anniversary of the Pearl Harbor attack. The president now signing an action saying this is Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day. Flags all around the country flying in half-staff today in honor of the more than 2400 servicemen who were killed and the nearly 1200 wounded in the surprise attack.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: December 7, 1941, a date which we'll live in infamy. The United States of America was suddenly and deliberately attacked.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Next up, we have this story for you. Media pundits now condemning President Trump for saying Jerusalem is the capital of Israel, saying that the president broke 70 years of U.S. policy. But my next guest he is an expert, he says the media pundits they've got it totally wrong.

He's former Israel elite Special Forces member. He is Aaron Cohen, he joins me next. Stay right there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Whatever the outcome of the negotiations, as stated in our democratic platform, Jerusalem is still the capital of Israel, and must remain an undivided city accessible to all.

(APPLAUSE)

GEORGE W. BUSH, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: As soon as I take office, I will begin the process of moving the United States ambassador to the city of Israel as its capital.

OBAMA: Jerusalem will remain the capital of Israel and it must remain undivided.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: President Trump followed through on his campaign promise. He made Jerusalem; basically the United States will recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. It is the statement made by several past presidents. We just showed you Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, and Barack Obama. As well as democrat senators like Diane Feinstein have said the same thing. But the media now condemning President Trump for the move, saying he broke 70 years of U.S. policy. Roll tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: On the other major news tonight. President Trump reversing nearly 70 decades of U.S. policy, now recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: He had promised this day would come, but to hear these words from the White House was jaw-dropping. Not only signing a proclamation reversing nearly 70 years of U.S. policy, but starting plans to move the embassy to Jerusalem. No one else on earth has an embassy there.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The department is concern about any possible violent reaction to President Trump's announcement today.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The president here is making a risky bet that doing something different will eventually end up productive for peace talks, but he's about the only one making that bet.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Seven decades of U.S. policy changed in an instant.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Joining me now former Israel elite Special Forces member Aaron Cohen. Good to see you, sir.

(CROSSTALK)

AARON COHEN, FORMER ISRAEL ELITE FORCES MEMBER: Good to see you.

MACDONALD: Did President Trump reverse U.S. policy by acknowledging Jerusalem as the capital of Israel?

COHEN: If it's reversing U.S. policy, come again with that, sorry.

MACDONALD: Yes, did he reverse U.S. policy when he basically sign that order?

(CROSSTALK)

COHEN: No, I don't think so. I think this has nothing to do is reversing any policy. Israel had a very strong standing policy with U.S. a very strong standing relationship with Israel. It's been that way since Israel's inception. And having a declaration it isn't changing anything in regards to the U.S.'s ability to be able to continue to work with Israel working with the peace for this.

No relationship between moving the U.S. embassy to Jerusalem from tel Aviv. There's no connection in terms of U.S. policy.

MACDONALD: MSNBC's Chris Matthews wasted no time making doomsday predictions. Let's roll tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS MATTHEWS, HOST, MSNBC: People are going to die now because of what was said today.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: If we move that embassy to Jerusalem we could spark a full on intifada and real people could die.

MATTHEWS: I believe they will and I believe that's the horror. By the way, deaths are coming now because of this. You can just bet in the next few weeks we are going to help pay for this holy erratic decision by this president.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: I mean, predictions like that they're just succeeding to threats really. I mean, would they have this reaction in President Obama had made this decision?

COHEN: Probably not. Yes, not only the media hypocrisy coming, you know, from the left regarding this move to Jerusalem. The fact is this. There hasn't been peace in Israel; it went through Palestinians since the Israel's inception. Israel is always had a very complicated security apparatus. And again, I just don't think that there's any connection between any increased violence and what we've seen in the last 70 years.

MACDONALD: OK.

COHEN: There's no connections. It's absolutely ludicrous.

MACDONALD: Aaron Cohen, you're going to stay right there. You'll be back after the break. Next up, the president getting praise inside Israel for his executive order in Jerusalem. But remember when the media accuse President Trump of being anti-Semitic. We've got basically more discussion about this coming up. Stay right there. Don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The White House is now condemning the bomb threat. This, after President Trump twice last week dance around questions about anti-Semitism. The statement does not actually mentioned Jews, something the White House was also criticized for after statement put out on Holocaust Remembrance Day.

CUOMO: He hasn't tweeted about this with the ordinary vigor that the president usually brings the things he doesn't like. This is in no way meant as a suggestion that the president is somehow OK with this. He's never said anything like that. But it's what he doesn't say.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Why President Trump spoken out more vociferously against the wave of anti-Semitism that we're seeing?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: You sort of hear between the lines there that the president was being accused of being anti-Semitic. You sort of heard that, right.

The media taken back after President Trump, though, announced recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and that Tel Aviv would no longer house the U.S. embassy removed to Jerusalem.

Back with me now, former Israeli elite Special Forces member, Aaron Cohen. Did the media's anti-Semitic insinuations against Trump ever hold water?

COHEN: No, they don't hold water. I think everybody who's listening to these anti-Semitic claims knows to nod their head immediately. I mean, calling Donald Trump anti-Semitic, especially as it pertains to Israel is not only ludicrous. It's laughable. It's equivalent to calling Bibi Netanyahu anti-Semitic was the prime minister of Israel.

The fact is, is that Israel as the presidents have stated four or five incumbent presidents coming in have all stated that they are going to, you know, claim Jerusalem as the capital and move the embassy to Jerusalem. Trump did it. And so really what it shows is that he's able to stand on his ground and he's committed to being part with this one.

I think this is what people don't really understand. The Trump's commitment to Israel is a strategic decision as it relates to U.S. national security, Liz, and I'll tell you why.

Israel shares intelligence with the Americans and Israel has the finest intelligence agencies and apparatuses in the world. We have Jews who have been kicked out by every Muslim country in the world and forced to move to Israel, and therefore we can infiltrate those countries undetected and get that human intelligence which Israel shares with the United States and Trump understand that.

I don't think his concern with the anti-Sematic callouts.

MACDONALD: Yes.

COHEN: It's just not true. It's fable and just, you know, nonsense.

MACDONALD: And the broader geopolitical point is that Israel is aligning with Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates against Iran and against the Muslim Brotherhood, right?

COHEN: Correct.

MACDONALD: OK.

COHEN: And they are in these countries are Iran and the Muslim Brotherhood are enemies who have sworn on the destruction of the U.S. and this western values. So, all of those alignments are key to our national security.

MACDONALD: OK.

COHEN: The only real bigotry that's going on here is the Arab world against this little tiny nation surrounded by 20 Arab countries. The only bigotry that is going on here.

MACDONALD: Thank you, Aaron Cohen. Great to see you. We love having you on. Come back soon.

COHEN: Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: A big weakness in China's economy could threaten global growth. It's China heavily indebted banks. Now the International Monetary Fund recommended China's bank increase their capital buffers to protect against any sudden economic downturn following a really inflated credit boom there.

It's the first looksee by the IMF into China's bank those seven years. The IMF said its stress test show China's top four banks do have enough capital but the nation's little guy, the smaller banks appear vulnerable.

Breaking up, breaking news. The republican operative tells Fox that -- FoxArizona Republican Representative Trent Frank -- Franks. Trent Franks is expected to resign.

However, these are just reports so far, it is a fast-moving fluid situation. This could possibly be. Again, this is an allegation their charges. Reports coming in inappropriate behavior. That's not confirmed. We're staying on top of this quick moving developing story for you.

Hollywood celebrities now evacuating homes in the Los Angeles area amid the wildfire threat. Known liberal anti-Trump comic Chelsea Handler actually blaming it on the president.

Meteorologist Joe Bastardi is here to give Chelsea Handler a science lesson after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Numerous people in Los Angeles area, including celebrities evacuating their homes amid the wildfires there. We have a liberal anti- Trump comic Chelsea Handler blaming it on the president.

Chelsea Handler tweeting out quote, "Just evacuated my house. It's like Donald Trump is setting the world of fire, literally and figuratively." Handler tweeted yesterday. "Stay safe, everyone. Dark times."

Let's get to Weatherbell.com meteorologist Joe Bastardi. Is that possible, did Trump cause that fire to happen? I thought he was in Washington, D.C.

JOE BASTARDI, CHIEF FORECASTER, WEATHERBELL.COM: Well, you know, any comment I make will be portrayed as unsympathetic to the horrific situation that's going on out there and I certainly don't want to appear that way.

But let's set the record straight. First of all, there was supposed to be a permanent drought out in California, that's what we heard two or three years ago. When that drought reversed last winter with the tremendous rains, that proved that it wasn't a permanent drought. It was a temporary drought, I guess.

But it also led to something that made by company, maybe Ms. Handler would subscribe to our company. She would have known what was going to go on back in the spring.

My company said that this means a big wildfire season is likely on the way. Now why is that? Because when you have extra heavy rains in California during the winter months it means there's going to be more vegetation. That vegetation of course is going to dry out during the summer because the summers are dry out there and what does that mean. There's more fuel for these fires.

MACDONALD: Yes.

BASTARDI: In addition, there are many, many more people, Liz, living out in California now than there were, let's say in the 1950s, so we have many more people in harms, they build houses, great houses and that's fine, but there is a high risk of this type of thing happening in getting out of control in populated areas now because we more populated areas.

MACDONALD: You know, Chelsea Handler is just making a bad joke there. You say it's possible though that these fires were started by human beings. How so?

BASTARDI: Well, you have to wonder sometimes whether -- I can't say this, they have to investigate how these fires started whether it was arson, whether it was by mistake. Someone was camping out or, you know, there was a short-circuit in a transmission box.

You know, all these things are possible and certainly, I mean, there were no thunderstorms around. I don't think to set these fires off. So the folks that do that type of work will determine that. Now it's very warm and hot out there in the West Coast. It's been hot out there in the West Coast and that happens quite often when it does get very cold in the east.

One of the things we've been preaching since October is that December was going to be cold and snowy in the eastern part of the United States and Europe about to see that happen and this correlates quite often. So when you have the dryness in the west and the heat in the west a lot of times the cold air comes into the eastern part of the United States. And don't be surprises someone blames him if he tries to snow in New Orleans and it might try to snow as far south as New Orleans tomorrow afternoon or tomorrow night.

MACDONALD: Wow.

BASTARDI: Someone to blame global warming or Donald Trump on that.

MACDONALD: Joe Bastardi, we love having you on. Come back soon, sir.

BASTARDI: Well, thank you for having me.

MACDONALD: Sure. Firefighters are breathing life-threatening conditions as the Southern California wildfire hit the Los Angeles area.

Fox News Adam Housley is on the ground. Adam?

ADAM HOUSLEY, SENIOR CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: Yes. Liz, right now we're in front of the Thomas fires started Monday night, about 30 miles from where I'm standing over near town called Santa Paula. And you're going to see how airdrop here in a second here bringing in water.

This is one of the fingers of the fire, one of the front edges of the fire heading towards the town called Carpenteria. It's actually a neighboring Santa Barbara County; it's how far this fire has burned. And they're really trying to knock it down right now. There's not a lot of wind but the air quality is miserable as you can tell as I'm wearing a mask.

I'm going to step away. This is front edge right here. The helicopter is going to come in here in a second you'll see it. There's hand crews up here in very steep commissions and terrain. It's very dry right now but they're getting a huge break from Mother Nature.

There is literally no wind here and there was supposed to be wind gust today 30 to 40 miles an hour. We haven't seen wind gust at all, it's completely calm, completely still which is allowing helicopters to get in as well. They only can help campers how to battle when it's windy, it's battling to safety and being able to fly in that.

But also, when they drop the waters, it's likes spitting into the wind. In this case it's not like that. You can see very little air movement which really allows them to get them. What you're going to see them drop right here in the front edge and you'll see the smoke go up as it knocks it down.

They really been hammering this area now for the last hour, is on opportunity to stop this blanket the fire. Another point nearby burned down right to the ocean and of course, that stopped it. There they goes right there, you see how close they get in and basically knock the entire flameout right there. A little bit left. He'll come back in here about every three or two to three minutes he turns around and comes back.

But they're doing a great job in right now knocking this down. And Liz, as you can tell it's quite a firefighters here in Southern California and you see the red flag alert will continue into Saturday.

Back to you.

MACDONALD: Great report. Adam, stay safe there, sir. Thank you so much.

HOUSLEY: We'll do.

MACDONALD: That was terrific reporting. Thank you.

Let's get to this story. Bitcoin continuing its meteoric rise today. Early investors the Winklevoss twins, a Facebook fame becoming Bitcoin billionaires.

Now many Americans are thinking you know what? It could be their lottery ticket too.

Next, our panel, managing money management on what to watch out for and whether it's too late to get in there, after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Breaking news. The majority of the Senate voting to pass the temporary two week spending measure that the House just passed all to avoid a government shutdown tomorrow night. Voting continues both republican and democrat leaders met at the White House today to discuss an agreement to fund the federal government.

It's called the continuing resolution. It simply renews all existing money for all government programs through midnight on December 22nd.

The price of Bitcoin swinging wildly today, rising to more than 19,000 only to fall sharply within minutes, still at a new highs surpassing 17,000. The frenzy surrounding this virtual currently escalating just days before it start trading on a major U.S. exchange.

In recent months this crypto currency has undergone a staggering increase in value surging from about 3500 in mid-September to its current price. Now for its perspective the Bitcoin is worth about eight times now as gold as the market cap higher than IBM, McDonald's or Disney. It's five times more expensive than the .com stocks were at the height of the internet mania.

Let's bring in the money managers, the go to guys on Wall Street, Jonathan Hoenig and Jason Rotman join me now.

Jonathan, without getting into the weeds can you explain to -- Bitcoin to people?

JONATHAN HOENIG, FOUNDING MEMBER, CAPITALIST PIG ASSET MANAGEMENT: Yes, it's a bubble. I mean, that's what this is at, E-Mac. This is a bubble. The price of Bitcoin has doubled in just the last two weeks alone. But because of the bubble, Liz, doesn't mean that the price can't continue to go up. I think back when you talk about some of the .com stocks thing, one of the '96, '97, '98, and then in '99 they went up another 100 percent.

So this doesn't matter what the technology is, what the assets are. The hunt is on for Bitcoin and as long as the price continues to climb I think buyers continue to show up especially since futures, as you mention, launching this weekend.

This is a bubble with no sign of turning around.

MACDONALD: Yes. You know, to Jonathan's point, Jason, do you -- would you get into it now or would you short it, what's your advice?

JASON ROTMAN, MANAGING PARTNER, LIDO ISLE ADVISORS: I would do neither. I would actually look at the other coins and other businesses in the block chain space that are much cheaper that have much bigger upside that do much more than just Bitcoin. Bitcoin is just money.

MACDONALD: Like what?

ROTMAN: There's other companies. Gosh, I mean, ethereum is kind of the second one to Bitcoin from a market cap standpoint. Ethereum is a whole platform there's another Chinese ethereum called nil. I think all these different companies have a much bigger future because they are the backbone of the whole decentralized economy.

Bitcoin is just money and I would not buy it up here especially.

MACDONALD: Yes, no store of value. Jonathan, what's going to cause this bubble to burst?

HOENIG: Well, you know, what's going to cause the bubble and the globe.com to burst. I mean, we don't know, Liz. That was, you know, a big tech of bigger play 20 years ago. Let's just emphasize, though, Bitcoin is not a currency. It is not a medium of exchange. It's not a store value. It's a speculation.

MACDONALD: OK.

HOENIG: And you know what this bull mark can continue to keep going but I wouldn't put my retirement fund there both in $20,000 coins.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: OK. Both of you think -- both of you think Bitcoin is a bubble in search of a pen. Jonathan and Jason, you both are great one. We want to have you back on soon. Thanks so much to you guys.

ROTMAN: Thanks, Liz.

HOENIG: Thank you.

MACDONALD: We will be right back. Stay right there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Well, it looks like there will not be a Christmas government shut down. The Senate voting to pass too temporary two week spending measures the House passed it as well, all to avoid that government shut down tomorrow night. The voting does continue.

We're staying on that story for you. We're simply with news all existing programs money for them through midnight on December 22nd.

Thanks so much for having us in your homes. Charles Payne is here now with Making Money. Take it away, Charles.

END

urn:contentItem:5R4H-0X51-DXH2-61WD-00000-00Senator Al Franken Announced That He Will Resign From The U.S. Senate In The Coming Weeks But Did Not Specifically Say The Exact Date; Former President Obama Taking Credit For The Booming Economy That Is Seen In The Trump Administration Now; Media Pundits Say That President Trump Broke The 70 Years Of U.S. Policy By Declaring Jerusalem As The Capital Of Israel; The Justice Department Is Now Going Through Over 10,000 Texts Between FBI Agent Peter Strzok And Another Official2017-12-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisRISK & REWARD5:00 PM ESTDavid Bossie, Corey LewandowskiNEWSFinancial120701cb.233Senator Al Franken Announced That He Will Resign From The U.S. Senate In The Coming Weeks But Did Not Specifically Say The Exact Date; Former President Obama Taking Credit For The Booming Economy That Is Seen In The Trump Administration Now; Media Pundits Say That President Trump Broke The 70 Years Of U.S. Policy By Declaring Jerusalem As The Capital Of Israel; The Justice Department Is Now Going Through Over 10,000 Texts Between FBI Agent Peter Strzok And Another OfficialElizabeth MacDonald, Nicole Petallides, Gregg Jarrett

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I hope that he'll do the right thing and step aside.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I feel there have been a series of allegations that are serious that when he speaks to the nation and to folks back in Minnesota to be the best step for him to step down.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I do not feel that he should continue to serve. Everyone will make their own judgment. I hope they do make their own judgment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, HOST, FOX NEWS: Senator Al Franken baffled under democrat pressure says he will resign. But quote, "In coming weeks" as he strongly defends himself against allegations of sexual misconduct. This is bare-knuckle political hardball. The push is now on for a democrat Senate majority to upend the Trump agenda. We have the details.

Also the House is passing a two week spending bill to avoid a government shutdown tomorrow night. This continuing resolution simply renews all existing programs for -- through basically the stroke of midnight December 22nd. We're on that story for you.

And Bitcoin crossing the 19,000 threshold for the very first time today. This crypto currency is in a staggering dizzying ascend surging from about 3500 in mid-September to its current price.

Did you miss the chance to get in on the action or to short Bitcoin? We're going to let you know. We have an all-star guest line-up including the co- authors of the new bestseller "Let Trump be Trump," they are David Bossie and Corey Lewandowski, also attorney Gregg Jarrett on the Mueller probe, and Fox Newshost Steve Hilton on the fight between Trump and Britain's Theresa May, all here all tonight.

I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. Risk and Reward starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AL FRANKEN, (D) UNITED STATES SENATOR: We were finally beginning to listen to women about the ways in which men's actions affect them. I was excited for that conversation. Then the conversation turned to me. Some of the allegations against me are simply not true. Others I remember very differently.

I have used my power to be a champion of women. Nothing I have done as a senator, nothing has brought this honor on this institution. Nevertheless, today, I am announcing that in the coming weeks I will be resigning as a member of the United States Senate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: He struck a defiant tone on the floor of the Senate. Senator Al Franken defended himself before announcing he will step down but with the caveat in coming weeks. That's what the Washington, D.C. echo chamber into overdrive that Al Franken may be trying to buy time to get a new lifeline out of the outcome of the Roy Moore Alabama Senate race.

This, after eight women now accuse Al Franken of touching them inappropriately. More than three dozen Senate democrats call for Al Franken's resignation, including Charles Schumer, Bernie Sanders, and Diane Feinstein. Al Franken is the second lawmaker to depart over sexual misconduct allegations in the last week after John Conyers said he would require.

The push is now on in the Senate for the democrats to seize control. And here's the math if democrats win the seats from retiring Senators Blake and Corker and there is a Roy Moore Senate loss that will put the democrats up 51-49.

Let's bring in the co-authors of "Let Trump be Trump: The Inside Story of His Rise to the Presidency" David Bossie and Corey Lewandowski join me now. Good to see you, guys. First, what do you think of Al Franken resigning, first to you, Corey.

COREY LEWANDOWSKI, CO-AUTHOR, LET TRUMP BE TRUMP: Look, I'd love to hear the definitive date that Al Franken is actually to walk away from the U.S. Senate because in Washington, D.C., Liz, I think you're exactly right. He says he's going to do it sometime in the future. The uproar goes away and Al Franken still sitting in the U.S. Senate a week, a month or a year from now because nobody is going to force him out.

More than 75 percent of his own democratic caucus has asked for him to resign. He's made the statement let's get the definitive date when he's going to leave.

MACDONALD: You know, David, the republicans now have Roy Moore problem. The democrats, David, are trying to rebrand themselves as a party above moral reproach. But you know, none have given back the Harvey Weinstein donations. And only one, Kirsten Gillibrand barely criticizes Bill Clinton.

Go ahead, David.

DAVID BOSSIE, CO-AUTHOR, LET TRUMP BE TRUMP: Yes. You know, I think that we are going to have to have this conversation continuously over the next, you know, coming weeks and months. You know, I think that when Alabama voters decide next week then the Senate will get to decide if they want to take action through the ethics committee on then-Senator Moore if he's elected.

So, we'll see. Look, this is not going away. It's not a conversation that should go away. You know, the members of the media, members of the political class, you know, need to be held to account. And whether you're in Hollywood, New York, Washington, you know, I am glad that this conversation is happening.

MACDONALD: Especially with that slush fund paying off sexual harassment cases and more. Let's get back to Franken. Corey, Al Franken is saying while in office he has used his power against women. Let's roll tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

FRANKEN: You know, an important part of the conversation we've been having in the last few months has been about how men abuse their power and privilege to hurt women. I am proud that during my time in the Senate I have used my power to be a champion of women. I know there's been a very different picture of me painted over the last few weeks but I know who I really am.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right, guys. OK, of course, Al Franken will say that. He has already made similar statements. He also took a shot of President Trump and Roy Moore. But you know, you talked in your book about the Access Hollywood tape, Corey. What was -- we want to know, what was the first lady's reaction to that and the first family, the president's daughters, what was their reaction to the Access Hollywood tape?

LEWANDOWSKI: You know, Melania Trump said that she knows her husband and this was locker room talk. It was boy talk is what she said. And she stood by her husband. She was very clear. And the president has said that he never did those things, which is very different than what Senator Franken has said.

Senator Franken has now admitted that he has done some of the things he has been accused of, some of those women have come forward and said that he did this while he was the United States senator. We have a picture of him groping a woman's breast while she's asleep on an airplane.

Look, where I come from there is something called street justice. If you were to do that where I come there would be a very different resolution and potentially going to the Senate ethics committee to determine if this was right or wrong.

It is uncalled for, it's egregious and Senator Franken should step down immediately and not some arbitrary date in the future where he hasn't told us when he is going to leave.

MACDONALD: David, speak about the 16 women who have accused President Trump in misconduct. Go ahead.

BOSSIE: Well, it is exactly what Corey said, which is one is -- one is locker room talk. One is, you know, guys talking among themselves whether you like it or not we all know what happens and that's what the president acknowledge.

But there is a difference between photographic evidence like in Al Franken's case or in these congressional race -- congressional cases where they use taxpayer dollars to pay the women off. So, we know there is evidence in those cases.

MACDONALD: OK.

BOSSIE: Here there is just a big difference between the two.

MACDONALD: I want to get to FBI director Christopher Wray defending the FBI after President Trump's criticism as the president -- excuse me -- Representative Jim Jordan really pushed card on the Robert Mueller Russia probe calling for a second special counsel to look into the FISA warrant and how they came about to basically spy on Trump campaign aides. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JIM JORDAN, (R) UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Peter Strzok, Mr. Super- agent at the FBI, I think he's the guy who took the application to the FISA court. And if that happened, I mean, think, if this happened if you have the FBI working with a campaign, the democrats campaign taken opposition research dressing it all up and turn it into an intelligence document and taking it to the FISA court so they can spy on the other campaign, if that happened that is as wrong as it gets.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. You guys were on the campaign, tell us what was going on behind the scenes of the campaign. Did you, Corey, did you -- did you know anybody or anyone else connected to the Trump campaign who is working with the Russians to hack Hillary Clinton's campaign.

LEWANDOWSKI: Never. And let me say this. I sat next to candidate Trump for 18 months, 18 hours a day seven days a week. Never was the collusion, cooperation or coordination with Russia in any way shape or form.

And what I have said very publicly and I stand by. If anybody attempted to or did manipulate the outcome of this election for a foreign government that person should go to jail for the rest of their life. And that would include FBI agents who potentially used their power in the deep state to manipulate government agencies like in court to list -- enlist FISA warrant or to change rules and regulations as it relate to Hillary Clinton investigation.

I am gravely concerned about this agent. And right now all we know is that he's been demoted to the human resources department which I think is still circumspect at best.

urn:contentItem:5PXG-SWS1-F03R-N33F-00000-00Senator Al Franken Floats Net Neutrality For Websites2017-11-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisSenator Al Franken Floats Net Neutrality For WebsitesAJ Dellinger

Nov 09, 2017( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex) While the Republican-controlled United States Federal Communications Commission prepares to roll back net neutrality rules for internet service providers, at least one Democrat is exploring the possibility of expanding such regulations to websites. Senator Al Franken, D-MN, suggested in a speech and an op-ed that rules requiring neutral treatment of information should be applied to giant tech platforms including Facebook, Google and Amazon. "As tech giants become a new kind of Internet gatekeeper, I believe the same basic principles of net neutrality should apply here: no one company should have the power to pick and choose which content reaches consumers and which doesn't," Franken wrote in an op-ed for the Guardian[1]. "Facebook, Google, and Amazon—like ISPs—should be 'neutral' in their treatment of the flow of lawful information and commerce on their platforms."

According to Franken, tech companies have consolidated so much power that they have effectively created monopolies in their own industries, leaving internet users with few or no viable alternatives. Net neutrality[2] prohibits ISPs from throttling or slowing a user's connection, blocking content, or providing preferential treatment to sites or services that pay extra for it. Such rules were applied to ISPs because most consumers only have the choice of one or two providers in their market. The rules did not extend to websites because users could easily visit any site they so chose as long as net neutrality was being enforced. Now, as users have grown reliant on just a few major platforms, some are beginning to size up those platforms as potential monopolies. The U.S. Federal Trade Commission can use its antitrust enforcement powers against sites, but Senator Franken is pushing for a new type of regulation that would specifically target the dominant web platforms. The senator wrote that while users may not like the fact that their activity on Facebook is used to dictate what kinds of advertisements are displayed in their feed or their web browsing history and information in their Gmail account helps the search giant deliver targeted ads, most people aren't going to delete their accounts because they have become necessary aspects of the online experience. He suggests consumers should have more options than to just have to submit to the potentially invasive behavior of the platforms they use. 'Big tech has taken it upon itself to sort through all the viewpoints, news, and entertainment, and decide for us what we should read, watch, buy, or even how we should engage in civil society,' Sen. Franken wrote. 'And they're doing it all under the shadow of complicated algorithms that make little sense to either the content creators whose livelihood depends on them or the users whose everyday decisions they're controlling.' The senator warned against the growing amount of traffic that web giants like Facebook and Google handle, noting that reliance on the sites offer the companies leverage in negotiating who gets to use their platforms and how—the same way Amazon used its control over the e-book market against publishers to force them into unfavorable contracts. During a speech at the Open Markets Institute[3] Thursday, Franken again called for a sort of net neutrality for websites that would help prevent against discriminatory behavior that may harm consumers and organizations that use the platforms. The Senator has not proposed any specific policy regarding how website and platforms should be regulated, and his position runs counter to what what Democrats once argued in regard to net neutrality—that it applied to internet service providers but not to websites. International Business Times contacted Facebook, Google, Amazon and the Internet Association—a trade group that represents all three companies—regarding Senator Franken's comments. Google, Facebook and the Internet Association did not respond at the time of publication. A spokesperson for Amazon declined to provide comment. "We don't want anybody to have the power to dictate somebody else's speech or commerce for them," Wood said.

urn:contentItem:5V0W-VM21-JBJH-30RH-00000-00Senator Amy Klobuchar Discusses Legislative Efforts To Regulate Facebook2018-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisAll Things Considered08:00 PM ESTMary Louise KellyAmy KlobucharSenator Amy Klobuchar Discusses Legislative Efforts To Regulate Facebook

MARY LOUISE KELLY: Facebook has been sharing users' personal data with some of the world's largest technology companies. And that is according to a new report in The New York Times. The newspaper obtained documents that show the social media giant allowed Microsoft's Bing search engine to see the names of virtually all Facebook users' friends without consent. The social network also permitted Amazon to obtain usernames and contact information through their friends.

AILSA CHANG: The data-sharing was meant to benefit all the companies. Facebook got more users and raked in advertising dollars. The Times reports that other companies acquired features to make the products more attractive. The question now is - what is the impact on all of us who use Facebook? Let's bring in Senator Amy Klobuchar.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: She's a Democrat from Minnesota. She sits on the Senate Judiciary Committee, also the Senate Commerce Committee. She has introduced legislation to strengthen protection of people's privacy online, and she is here in our studio.

Senator, welcome.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: Well, thanks, Mary Louise. It's great to be on.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: It does seem as though every day - or something like that - another shoe drops when we talk about Facebook. What is your top line reaction to this latest investigation by The New York Times?

AMY KLOBUCHAR: Well, I'm not completely surprised. But I think the evidence is becoming so overwhelming that we can no longer be paralyzed. It feels like - these companies, they somehow thought for years that they could just be bystanders in what is a never-ending cyberwar. And in fact, they've been used, they've made money off of it big time, and it is time to step in. And at the same time, Congress has been paralyzed. Nothing has been happening. Whether it's because of lobbying, whether it's because of the complexity of this, we just have to put all that aside and move.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: On the specific revelations that are coming out, the part I found most unsettling is this revelation that Spotify and Netflix, two other big tech companies, could read our private messages on Facebook.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: It is an unbelievable thought. So you are, you know, going back and forth with your mom and - about what movie they liked or what movie they were going to see and then - on Facebook. Never in a million years do people think that is then going to go to Netflix so that can presumably direct things at you, if you have an account with them, or try to lure you into their service by advertising things - or the same with music and Spotify.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: But to your point that we - you said we should not be surprised - I mean, should we be surprised? Or should we just accept that...

AMY KLOBUCHAR: I'm not surprised...

MARY LOUISE KELLY: ...If we type anything anywhere online, we don't quite know in 2019, 2018 - in the digital age - where it's going to end up and who might see it?

AMY KLOBUCHAR: I think we have to expect more - more from these companies. And that means, first of all, that they can't be messing around with private data. And to me, they're clearly not going to police themselves. So that's why we have to pass privacy legislation. Think about if we had in place the legislation - bipartisan legislation that I've introduced with Senator Kennedy of Louisiana. First...

MARY LOUISE KELLY: This is the legislation I referenced that you introduced in April.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: I think it would have fixed a lot of this. First, plain language - you'd have to make a decision if you're going to share your data. You'd have to understand that more. Secondly, you'd have control over your data and that you would be able to opt out of any sharing arrangements. And the third thing is that you would be notified of any privacy breach. That is pretty common-sense legislation.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: If it's common-sense legislation, why weren't you able to get it out of committee? It never even came up for a vote.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: Right. And I think a lot of that has to do with the lobbying that goes on from the tech industry. And I believe that our colleagues in both the Commerce Committee, Judiciary and the Republican majority is going to have to step up here because...

MARY LOUISE KELLY: Is it also...

AMY KLOBUCHAR: ...You can no longer just pretend - hey, we don't want to regulate things - when people's privacy is being breached on a daily basis.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: One question that's come up is whether Facebook violated the 2011 Federal Trade Commission settlement. The settlement...

AMY KLOBUCHAR: The consent decree.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: Yeah, exactly. Consent degree, it required getting users' explicit consent before their information is shared beyond the privacy settings that Facebook has established. In your view, was that FTC agreement violated?

AMY KLOBUCHAR: That FTC agreement was about not sharing personal data. So I don't quite understand how it couldn't have been violated. That is something that they are debating, I'm sure, at the FTC. But this feels like a different level of wrongdoing because when Mark Zuckerberg appeared before us, the joint Senate and Commerce committees, you know, we never heard anything about this. And when you think about it, a lot of this seemed to have ended right when they were getting caught.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: To Zuckerberg's role, how should he be held accountable? Should he go?

AMY KLOBUCHAR: Well, one of the bills that's pretty interesting - and I'm not going to the internal decisions in the company - but is Data Care Act, which would put that kind of accountability on the company, creating a fiduciary duty for these companies to protect their information, just like you have for doctors, just like you have for lawyers. And I think we need to start...

MARY LOUISE KELLY: But in terms of Congress, super-overseeing this company...

AMY KLOBUCHAR: But that would be...

MARY LOUISE KELLY: ...You're not going to get into what this company should do in terms of who should be leading it.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: I think that that's going to be a decision of the company, of the shareholders. But I do think if you look at it in a bigger, more systemic way with tech, the answer is to create a standard, a fiduciary duty because, again, they have literally been coming into our office and saying - hey, we can take care of ourselves, and it's really complicated. Well, they can't. OK? They have created this monster, basically, that has so many good things that's part of it. There's a friendly part of the monster. But then it has created vulnerabilities for our democracy, vulnerabilities for cyberattacks, vulnerabilities for stealing data and intruding on people's privacy.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: Change of subject, if I may - are you running for president in 2020?

AMY KLOBUCHAR: I am considering it. And...

MARY LOUISE KELLY: You're smiling, I should say.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: I'm considering it and talking to...

MARY LOUISE KELLY: You showed up in Iowa recently.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: There we are. Well, you know, Minnesotans like to go south for the winter.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: (Laughter).

AMY KLOBUCHAR: And talking with people who I've worked with for many years and with my family, I had the unfortunate experience, when I decided to look at running for Senate, of my husband finding out about it on the radio when I did an interview just like this before I had discussed it with him.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: Well, feel free to break news...

AMY KLOBUCHAR: There you go.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: ...And surprise him again.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: No, I don't think so. So anyway - so I'm considering it. I think it's important to have a lot of different voices from different parts of the country.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: What might tip the balance for you?

AMY KLOBUCHAR: Again, you have to - it is a daunting decision, and you have to decide that you would want to do this, that you have that capacity to win, that you are someone that can beat Donald Trump and that would be a good president. And those are all separate things. And so I think you've got to make that decision with an affirmative yes to all of them.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: I do notice that some of your fellow senators and potential competitors, should you decide to run for the Democratic nomination, have been polishing the foreign policy pages of their resumes. Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren just gave big foreign policy speeches recently. Kamala Harris just showed up in Afghanistan. Any travel plans - dropping by Afghanistan, Iraq over the holidays?

AMY KLOBUCHAR: (Laughter) Well, I've gone to both places in the past and have really worked hard on some of these issues from my position on the Judiciary Committee because we had jurisdiction over some of the terrorism laws. I also am a former prosecutor. And I've also worked on...

MARY LOUISE KELLY: Although you don't currently have a committee seat on Foreign Affairs or Armed Services...

AMY KLOBUCHAR: No, but I'm on Judiciary...

MARY LOUISE KELLY: ...Or Intelligence.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: And then Minnesota has a huge refugee population, so I've worked on that issue all over the world as well. So I think any member of this Senate has to be able to show their foreign relations chops at any moment, whether it was the recent debate we had on Yemen or whether it is trade issues or working with our allies. So thinking, it's something that you have to do as part of being a senator.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota.

Best of luck as you make up your mind. And thanks for stopping by.

AMY KLOBUCHAR: Thank you.

MARY LOUISE KELLY: And to circle back to the Facebook part of that interview, we did ask them for a statement. And they sent us this - quote, "Facebook's partners don't get to ignore people's privacy settings, and it's wrong to suggest that they do." Facebook also wrote, "we know we've got work to do to regain people's trust. Protecting people's information requires stronger teams, better technology and clearer policies. And that's where we have been focused for most of 2018."

urn:contentItem:5W0W-67R1-JCBF-S051-00000-00SENATOR BLACKBURN INTRODUCES BROWSER ACT IN THE SENATE2019-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:58ZLexisNexisSENATOR BLACKBURN INTRODUCES BROWSER ACT IN THE SENATEStates News ServiceWASHINGTON, D.C.

The following information was released by Tennessee Senator Marsha Blackburn:

Today, Senator Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.) spoke on the Senate Floor about her introduction of S.1116, the Balancing the Rights of Web Surfers Equally and Responsibly (BROWSER) Act. The BROWSER Act requires communications and technology companies to provide users with clear and conspicuous notice of their privacy policies and the ability to opt-in to the collection of sensitive information and to opt-out of the collection of non-sensitive information. It also prohibits these companies from denying their service to users who refuse to waive their privacy rights, empowers the Federal Trade Commission to enforce these rules, and ensures we have a consistent national law regarding online privacy.

Watch Senator Blackburn's full floor remarks by clicking below or HERE.

Senator Blackburn previously introduced this bill in the House of Representatives during the 115th Congress.

Transcript of Floor Remarks (as prepared):

Today, I rise to speak to you about the legislation I introduced in the Senate this week: S. 1116, the BROWSER Act.

Broadband, or high-speed internet, has absolutely revolutionized the way we communicate, the way we conduct commerce and, actually, the way we participate in government.

Broadband is one of the greatest innovations in history.

It allows near instantaneous exchange of information and brings efficiencies to the daily lives of millions of Americans as they move more of their transactional life online.

Thanks to Broadband, entrepreneurs have been able to bring thousands of new applications to consumers.

These "edge services" are now an essential part of our lives.

We find ourselves everyday saying, "I can't imagine what we did before we had this, or before we had that."

These "apps" give consumers access to entertainment, news, information, help us drive around town, and access to emergency services.

As consumers use these apps, they generate massive amounts of data about themselves... and that is the problem.

Many companies collect this data and use it for a range of purposes without the user's knowledge.

Without your knowledge. They're collecting all this.

Every bill you pay and every website that you visit.

These platforms are following you.

So, Mr. President, after all this information is shared, the question is:

Who owns the Virtual You?

Who owns you and your presence online? Our laws have not kept pace with technological change.

Now, we see some states and we've even got some cities that are adding more complexity to the problem by enacting their own privacy rules and standards, despite the fact that digital commerce is not restricted to one area.

Digital commerce is interstate and global in nature.

Mr. President, it is time we had a consistent national law regarding online privacy.

We need one set of rules and one regulator for the entire internet ecosystem. It just makes sense.

That is why I introduced the legislation I previously proposed as a member of the House of Representatives. And, as I said, it is called the BROWSER Act.

Americans want to be certain that their privacy is protected both in the physical and the virtual space.

Broadband users, which are each and every one of us, should have the right to say who can or cannot access their private data.

Think about it. At this point, how and when you pay your bills, the credit cards that you use, the sites that you visit, the merchandise that you shop for, friends that you connect with.

There is somebody tracking that activity.

Every move of the mouse: they're on it.

Consumers should have the right to clear and conspicuous notice of service provider's privacy policies, and the ability to either opt-in or opt-out depending on the sensitive nature of that data.

The BROWSER Act requires digital service to provide users with clear and conspicuous notice of their rights.

It also requires digital services to provide users the ability to opt-in to the collection of sensitive information while also giving users the ability to opt-out of the collection of non-sensitive information.

By allowing for a clear and conspicuous notification process, consumers will be able to make a more educated choice about the nature of the relationships they want to have with online vendors and with tech companies.

Furthermore, the BROWSER Act will prohibit digital services from denying the service to users who refuse to waive their personal privacy rights.

The BROWSER Act also empowers the FTC (the Federal Trade Commission) to enforce these rules using its unfair or deceptive acts or practices authorities.

Now, the FTC has been our privacy regulator in both the physical and the online space.

Just this week, Senator Klobuchar and I sent a letter to the FTC urging stronger action for bad actors in the tech space.

Companies like Facebook and Google have transformed society in revolutionary ways and need to recognize that with that great power, comes great responsibility.

This is the 21st century. It is not the Wild West.

These tech companies need to be respectful of your privacy rights.

My hope is through bipartisan effort, we will shed light on the need to protect online competition and privacy to keep up with the fast pace changes in technology.

The FTC has a responsibility to hold tech companies accountable for securing their platforms.

We need them to step up and be the cop on the beat in the virtual space.

Before I yield the floor, I want to make one last point.

The BROWSER Act treats everyone in broadband and edge companies the same.

One regulator, one set of rules: this is commonsense.

Unfortunately, yesterday, Democrats in the House passed a bill to regulate broadband service providers.

But, guess what? Guess what?

They didn't do anything to big tech.

They didn't do anything about privacy with Google, with Facebook, with Yahoo these people that collect your data and sell it to the highest bidder and then that person markets back to you.

When I chaired the Communications Subcommittee in the House, I repeatedly offered to work with the other side of the aisle to preserve a free and open internet.

I am always happy to work together to find a legislative solution and put this so-called Net Neutrality issue to rest once and for all.

But, rather than work together on this, the House pushed through a hyper-partisan bill to re-instate a controversial heavy-handed regulation of communications companies.

But, Heaven forbid, they do not want to touch Big Tech who are their big buddies.

Leader McConnell has said, and I am so grateful he has said, this bill coming from the House is "dead on arrival" in the Senate... and I look forward to continuing to work on this issue.

But, here is what my friends across the aisle and my friends in the House need to realize: the internet is not broken. The internet is not broken.

Many of you, Madam President, probably have an electronic device close at hand. It is working just fine.

The internet does not need the intervention of Nancy Pelosi and House Democrats. It is just fine. It is going to be fine by itself.

In fact, as an alternative, we could just strike out the text of the House bill and insert the BROWSER Act in its place.

One set of rules. One set of rules for the entire internet ecosystem.

One set of rules enforced by one federal regulator. That's the BROWSER Act. It's about fairness.

It's about encouraging innovation. It's about making certain we keep a fair and open Internet.

Madam President, I yield the floor.
